Both Republicans and Democrats receive similar public assessments regarding their policy ideas and ethical standards, with roughly equal percentages perceiving each party as having high ethical standards [1, 2, 3].  Interestingly, identical percentages of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, as well as Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents, reported following news about the upcoming elections either very or fairly closely [10].  However, when examining the specific trait ratings, the Democratic Party edges out the Republican Party in public perception, achieving a slightly higher combined percentage for both 'good policy ideas' and 'high ethical standards' as illustrated in the survey results.

![The Democratic Party and the Republican Party are perceived to have similar levels of good policy ideas and high ethical standards.](image7)

Despite the close overall ratings and similar levels of news engagement across party lines [10], a deeper look at the engagement levels reveals that only a segment of Democrats who closely followed election news.  Specifically, among Democrats and those who lean Democratic, just 22% indicated that they followed news about congressional elections in their state or district very closely.

![Among Democrats and Democrat-leaning individuals, 22% reported following election news very closely.](image4)

Therefore, among the party with the highest total percentage of good policy ideas and high ethical standards, 22% reported following news about congressional elections in their state very closely.

Indonesia's telecommunications landscape in 2014 showed notable shifts compared to the preceding years. Examining the operators, we see a landscape populated by major players alongside emerging and transitioning entities.  In the period of 2013-2014, key operators included Telkomsel, XL, Indosat, 3, Smartfren, and Esia, as highlighted by subscriber data [5, image5].  However, by late 2014, while Telkomsel, XL, and Indosat remained prominent, particularly in terms of data users [image8], the dynamics were changing.

The CDMA operators, like Telkom Flexi and StarOne, faced a wave of mergers, with Telkom Flexi merging into Telkomsel and StarOne into Indosat [10]. This consolidation marks a significant shift from the operator landscape of 2013-2014.  Furthermore, 2014 witnessed the rise of new contenders in the market, notably Bolt 4G as the first commercial LTE operator and WiGO as a WiMAX operator, representing new technologies and market entrants not explicitly present in the 2013-2014 operator lists [10].  These new entrants and the consolidation of CDMA operators illustrate the evolving nature of the telecom operator ecosystem.

Therefore, when comparing the telecom operators in 2014 to those of 2013-2014, the operators not in common, reflecting the changes and additions in 2014, are ["Telkom Flexi", "StarOne", "Bolt 4G", "WiGO"].

Final Answer: ["Telkom Flexi", "StarOne", "Bolt 4G", "WiGO"]

Public opinion regarding the fairness of Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian involvement in the 2016 election has remained quite consistent over time [8].  A notable aspect is the partisan divide in these views, with Democrats generally expressing more confidence in the investigation's fairness compared to Republicans [3].  While a majority of the public maintains some level of confidence in Mueller's fair conduct [4], delving into specific levels of confidence reveals nuanced shifts.  For instance, examining the levels of "very confident" and "not too confident" provides a more detailed picture of public sentiment.  ![This image shows the percentages of people who are "Not at all", "Not too", "Somewhat", and "Very" confident in Robert Mueller's fair investigation over time, from December 2017 to January 2019.](image5)  In January 2018, 29% of people reported being "very confident" in Mueller's fairness.  Fast forward to January 2019, and 30% expressed being "not too confident". The percentage point difference between those not too confident in January 2019 and those very confident in January 2018 is 1%.

Americans' trust in information sources regarding the coronavirus outbreak varies across demographics. Older adults express less trust in information from the World Health Organization (WHO) [image2], while those with postgraduate degrees show greater confidence in data from the European Union (EU) [image2].  According to a Pew Research Center study conducted in April-May 2020 [7], analysis of trust levels reveals that among individuals aged 65 and above, a total of 46% express distrust in WHO information, combining those who trust "not at all" (15%) and "not too much" (31%)  ![For individuals 65+, 46% do not trust information from the WHO.](image2). In contrast, among postgraduates, only 22% express distrust in EU information, derived from "not at all" (3%) and "not too much" (19%) ![For postgraduates, 22% do not trust information from the EU.](image2). Therefore, 24% more people over 65 years old do not trust information from the World Health Organization compared to postgraduates who do not trust information from the European Union in regard to the coronavirus outbreak.

Amid ongoing discussions about the rise in confirmed coronavirus cases, a notable viewpoint among Republicans is that increased testing, rather than new infections, is the primary driver.  As indicated, $62\%$ of Republicans hold this belief [1, 7]. This perspective is further illustrated, showing the specific percentage for Republican and Republican-leaning individuals who attribute the rise in cases to increased testing rather than new infections. ![Image shows that 62% of Rep/Lean Rep believe increased testing is the primary reason for rising cases.](image3)

Conversely, when it comes to responsibility for policies to limit the spread of COVID-19, Republicans largely favor state and local governments.  Specifically, $68\%$ of Republicans believe that state and local entities should be primarily responsible [3].  While public opinion is divided on whether the federal or state government should take the lead on COVID-19 policies, with a slight majority leaning towards state and local governments, partisan divides are evident in these views. ![Image shows the public opinion on whether the federal or state/local government should be primarily responsible for COVID-19 policies.](image2)

In conclusion, $62\%$ of Rep/Lean Rep believe cases have risen primarily because of more testing, and approximately $32\%$ of Rep/Lean Rep think the federal government should be primarily responsible for COVID-19 control policy (calculated as 100% - 68% who favor state/local responsibility).

Voters in 2016 perceived the presidential campaign as unusually negative, with an overwhelming majority noting more mudslinging compared to previous elections [6, 11].  This negativity contrasted with past elections where voter satisfaction with candidates was generally higher [2].  Even early in the 2016 race, satisfaction was low, with only 40% of registered voters feeling satisfied with their choices ![Voter satisfaction with candidates was generally higher in elections prior to 2016](image6).  Despite the negativity and perceived lack of issue discussion [1, 10], most voters felt they learned enough to make an informed choice, a sentiment visualized over different election years ![Most voters feel they learned enough to make an informed choice](image3). Presidential debates were considered helpful by a majority of voters in making their candidate decision, a trend consistent with recent elections ![Presidential debates are helpful for voters' decision](image4).  Interestingly, post-election reactions to Trump's victory were similar to reactions to Obama's victory four years prior in terms of happiness and unhappiness [7].  Evaluations of the press and pollsters were notably negative, with few voters giving them high grades [9].  A significant percentage of voters felt there was less discussion of issues in the 2016 election compared to previous ones ![Voters felt less discussion of issues in the 2016 election](image1), and overwhelmingly perceived more mudslinging ![Voters overwhelmingly perceived more mudslinging in the 2016 election](image7).  The 2016 campaign is largely viewed negatively in post-election assessments compared to elections since 1988 [12].

There are seven line plots in the report.

Even though many people hold a dim view of the ongoing military actions against ISIS in Iraq and Syria, with a substantial portion expressing that the efforts are "not too well or not at all well" [1], and as highlighted, "Few say current military effort in Iraq and Syria is going well" [12], there's a contrasting sense of optimism concerning the eventual victory of the U.S. and its allies. ![The percentage of people who believe US and allies will succeed is higher than those who believe they will fail, and the success belief increased from July to December 2015](image4).  Indeed, "two-thirds (66%) now say they think the U.S. and its allies will either definitely or probably succeed in their campaign against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria" [9]. In conclusion, despite negative perceptions of the current military progress, a majority still believed in the ultimate success of the U.S.-led campaign against ISIS in 2015.

In the 2022 midterms, Cuban voters showed a preference for Republican candidates, contrasting with most Mexican voters who leaned towards the Democratic party [2]. Notably, when compared to other Latino subgroups, Cuban registered voters are more inclined to want Trump to remain a significant figure in national politics; this contrasts with the lower percentages among Mexican and Puerto Rican voters who desire Trump to remain a major national figure [8].  Therefore, Cuban Americans are the Hispanic origin group most inclined to vote for a Republican candidate for the U.S. House of Representatives in their district and to support Donald Trump running for president in 2024.

Republican voters largely maintained their preference for a more conservative direction for the GOP from 2008 to 2016, with a consistent majority desiring the party to move further to the right [9]. This preference remained relatively stable over the years, indicating a consistent conservative leaning within the Republican voter base. ![Republican voters consistently favored a conservative direction from 2008 to 2016](image4). In contrast, Democratic voters experienced a notable shift in their political orientation during the same period. While in 2008 and the years following Obama's victories, a majority of Democrats favored a more moderate direction for their party [5], by 2016, there was a significant surge in support for a more liberal stance [4].  This change reflects a growing inclination among Democratic voters towards more liberal policies and ideologies, marking a departure from the more moderate preferences observed in earlier years. ![Democratic voters shifted from favoring a moderate direction to a more divided view with rising liberal preference from 2008 to 2016](image8).  From 2008 to 2016, Republican voters remained consistently conservative while Democratic voters shifted towards a more liberal political orientation.

Voter opinions regarding the appointment of opposition party members differed notably between the elections of Donald Trump and Barack Obama. In 2016, a small fraction of Trump's voters, specifically about a quarter, supported the idea of him appointing Democrats to his administration [7].  Indeed, considering key positions, even fewer Trump supporters were in favor of cross-party appointments [3, 4].  Juxtaposing this with the sentiment following Obama's 2008 victory, a significantly larger proportion of his voters, double the percentage of Trump's supporters, believed he should appoint Republicans to his cabinet [10].  ![Image showing the percentage of voters who think president should or should not appoint opposition party members in 2016 and 2008](image8). This demonstrates a clear contrast, indicating that Obama's voters were considerably more inclined towards cross-party appointments than Trump's voters.  In conclusion, Obama's voters were substantially more supportive of appointing opposition party members compared to Trump's voters.

Views on the likely success of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS saw a positive shift between July and December 2015.  In December, two-thirds of people believed that the U.S. and its allies would likely succeed in their campaign against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria [6].  This marked an 11-point increase from July, where only 55% held this view, while the percentage believing in failure decreased [6].  This shift is visually represented, showing a clear increase in the expectation of success and a decrease in the expectation of failure between July and December 2015 ![Shows the percentage change of belief in success and failure in US campaign against ISIS between July and December 2015](image5).  Although current ratings of the campaign's progress remained negative, there was a noticeable increase in the belief that ultimate success was achievable [2].  Despite these shifts in perceived success, overall approval for the U.S. military campaign remained steady throughout 2015 [11],  with a majority continuing to support it ![Shows the favorability of US military campaign against ISIS from Oct 2014 to Dec 2015](image3).

In summary, perceptions of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS became more optimistic regarding its potential for success between July and December 2015, even while overall approval for the campaign remained consistent.

Public perception regarding whether Islam is more prone to violence than other religions has been a subject of division in America, with opinions fluctuating over time.  While about 46% of Americans in December 2015 believed Islam is more likely to encourage violence, and 45% thought it was not, this reflects a slight decrease from a high of 50% in September 2014 [7].  The trend of public opinion on this matter has remained closely split for much of the last decade, as illustrated over time. ![Trend of public opinion on whether Islam is more likely to encourage violence, showing a divided view over time](image4)  Notably, while some attitudes on terrorism have decreased, perceptions of Islam and violence have shown less significant change overall [5].

However, a significant partisan divide exists and has even widened.  In late 2015, 68% of Republicans believed Islam encourages violence more than other religions, a figure consistent with the previous year but historically high [1, 11]. In stark contrast, only 30% of Democrats held this view, marking a decrease from 42% in September 2014 and aligning with Democratic opinions from previous years [1, 11]. This partisan gap is evident when comparing the views of Republicans, Independents, and Democrats across different years. ![Trend of partisan views on whether Islam encourages violence, highlighting the divergence between Republicans and Democrats](image2)  This ideological polarization is further emphasized by the opinions of conservative Republicans, where about three-quarters (77%) believe Islam is more likely to encourage violence, contrasting sharply with liberal Democrats, where 73% think Islam is no more violence-prone than other religions [4].  Examining further demographic breakdowns, we can see these diverging opinions across different groups. ![Demographic breakdown of opinions on whether Islam encourages violence, showing variations across political and demographic groups](image5)

Age also plays a role, with younger Americans aged 18 to 29 being less likely (32%) to perceive Islam as more violence-encouraging compared to older age groups [3]. Interestingly, the decrease in the perception of Islam being violence-prone is more pronounced among liberals, with a 14-point drop since fall 2014 [10].

In conclusion, perceptions on whether Islam encourages violence more than other religions have remained divided in the US, characterized by a significant and widening partisan gap, with Republicans more likely than Democrats to view Islam as violence-prone, although there has been a slight decrease in this perception among Democrats and the general public since 2014.

Americans are largely aware of the increasing capabilities of machines in performing tasks previously exclusive to humans [2].  This awareness, however, is often accompanied by apprehension rather than excitement.  Indeed, when considering a future where robots and computers can handle numerous human jobs, Americans are significantly more inclined to express worry (72%) than enthusiasm (33%) [1, 5].  This sentiment is further illustrated by the fact that a considerable portion of the population, one-in-five Americans, considers the concept of machines taking over most human jobs to be extremely realistic [3, 8, 7].

Despite this general sense of realism, levels of familiarity with the concept vary across the population [2].  While a large majority (85%) has heard or read about automation impacting jobs, a smaller portion (24%) reports in-depth knowledge [2].  Interestingly, those who are more informed about this prospect tend to perceive it as more realistic and exhibit higher levels of enthusiasm compared to those with less awareness [4, 9, 12]. This difference in perception based on awareness is visually represented, showing how those who have heard "a lot" are more likely to find the concept extremely realistic and somewhat enthusiastic, while also expressing more worry, compared to those who've heard "a little" or "nothing" ![Americans' views on the realism, enthusiasm, and worry about machines doing many human jobs, segmented by their level of awareness about the concept](image6).

The perceived consequences of widespread automation are multifaceted, encompassing both potential benefits and drawbacks.  When asked about possible outcomes, opinions are divided between negative possibilities such as increased inequality and people struggling to find purpose, and positive scenarios like greater economic efficiency and a shift towards more meaningful human pursuits ![Views on the potential positive and negative outcomes of machines doing jobs currently done by humans](image1).  To mitigate potential negative impacts and ensure a smooth transition in an automated future, various interventions are considered.  A notable majority supports limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, while ideas like universal basic income and national service programs also garner considerable, though somewhat more measured, support [6].  Support levels for these interventions, like limiting machines to dangerous jobs and guaranteeing a basic income, are further detailed, showing varying degrees of favor and opposition across different policy options ![Support and opposition levels for various policy interventions related to automation](image4).

In conclusion, Americans perceive the increasing capability of machines to perform human jobs as a realistic development, yet this recognition is predominantly overshadowed by worry rather than enthusiasm, with considerations for both negative and positive outcomes and varying degrees of support for potential societal interventions.

Public sentiment is notably divided on whether businesses should face restrictions on the extent to which they can automate jobs, yet a considerable majority leans towards imposing such limits [1].  This perspective is highlighted by the fact that 58% of Americans believe there should be boundaries on job automation, contrasting with 41% who think businesses should be free to replace human roles with machines for better and cheaper outcomes ![Public is split on limiting automation but more favor limits](image8).  Despite the even split in public opinion regarding whether the government or individuals should bear the responsibility for supporting displaced workers, there's a stronger consensus in favor of capping the number of human jobs that businesses can substitute with machines [2].

Interestingly, the public shows significant approval for policies that would confine the application of automation technologies to specific scenarios, particularly those that ensure human involvement remains central to operations [3].  A striking 85% of Americans advocate for limiting machines to roles that are inherently dangerous or detrimental to human health, should robots and computers become capable of performing numerous human tasks [4, 6].  This inclination towards prioritizing human safety and health in the context of automation is strongly favored across the population, as shown in ![Public strongly favors limiting machines to dangerous jobs and supports other policies](image1).  Even though opinions diverge on certain mitigation strategies along political lines, with Democrats showing greater support for universal basic income and national service programs compared to Republicans [7, 12], the broad agreement on limiting machines to dangerous and dirty jobs is a unifying sentiment [7].

In conclusion, public opinion generally favors limiting the use of machines in the workforce, especially by restricting them to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, and supports policies aimed at mitigating the impact of job displacement due to automation.

Current public opinion reveals a notable divide in perceptions of job availability across political lines.  While majorities in both parties acknowledge the abundance of jobs in their localities, a significant partisan gap persists [12].  For instance, a survey in January 2019 indicated that 71% of Republicans believed there were plenty of jobs available, compared to 53% of Democrats [2].  ![Republicans are more likely than Democrats to say plenty of jobs are available currently.](image6)  This difference is further highlighted when examining the trend over time, as illustrated in the graph, showing the diverging views between Republican and Democrat leaning individuals regarding job availability since 2001 ![Trend of job availability perception from 2001 to 2019, showing partisan divide.](image4). Despite this partisan divergence, it is important to note that views on local job opportunities are generally positive across both parties, reaching levels not seen in the last two decades [9, 11].  In conclusion, perceptions of job availability are significantly influenced by political affiliation, with Republicans consistently expressing more positive views than Democrats, although both groups acknowledge generally positive local job markets.

In January of 2019, a notable $70\%$ of Democrats favored their leaders confronting President Trump, even at the cost of legislative progress in Washington [1]. This represents an increase from the $63\%$ of Democrats who held this stance the previous year [1].  Similarly, Republican sentiment shifted, with $51\%$ in January 2019 wanting their leaders to challenge Democrats, up from $40\%$ in January 2018 [1].  Both Democrats and Republicans experienced an increase in the percentage of individuals wanting their leaders to 'stand up' to the opposition from January 2018 to January 2019.

Latino Democrats are significantly more inclined to perceive the lack of recognition of racial discrimination as a major societal problem compared to their Republican counterparts [8].  This is visually represented by the stark contrast in views, with a majority of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners  $(73\%)$  identifying the failure to see racial discrimination as the bigger issue, whereas a larger portion of Republicans and Republican leaners  $(62\%)$  believe the opposite – that people seeing racial discrimination where it doesn't exist is more problematic [8].  ![Image depicts the percentage of Latinos who think people not seeing racial discrimination is a bigger problem, broken down by party affiliation.](image1).  In fact, Latino Democrats  $(75\%)$  demonstrate a considerably higher likelihood than Latino Republicans  $(36\%)$  to consider the lack of acknowledgment of racial discrimination as a greater concern for the nation [2]. This disparity in perception remains consistent even when considering political leaners within each group [2]. Perceptions of racial discrimination are significantly different between Latino Democrats and Republicans.

Many Americans attribute the underrepresentation in STEM fields to a lack of early encouragement for girls, blacks, and Hispanics, with $39\%$ of Americans seeing this as a major factor for women and $41\%$ for blacks and Hispanics [1].  Those working in STEM jobs are even more likely to emphasize factors related to educational opportunities, noting limited access to quality education ($52\%$) and insufficient encouragement from an early age ($45\%$) as key reasons for the underrepresentation of blacks and Hispanics [8].  Discrimination is also highlighted, especially by black STEM workers, where a significant $62\%$ report experiencing workplace discrimination due to their race or ethnicity [2].  ![Major reasons for underrepresentation of women and minorities in STEM include lack of encouragement, discrimination, and limited access to quality education.](image5)  Furthermore, perceptions on the role of discrimination vary across racial groups; a large majority of blacks in STEM ($72\%$) believe discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions is a major barrier, contrasting sharply with the views of whites ($27\%$) and Asians ($28\%$) [4].  Other contributing factors considered by STEM workers include the belief among underrepresented groups that they may not succeed in STEM and the lack of visible role models [7].  In conclusion, the underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM is attributed to a combination of factors including lack of early encouragement, limited access to quality education, and experiences of discrimination, according to the Pew Research Center.

Most Americans tend to view K-12 STEM education as being of average or below-average quality when compared to other developed nations [1, 3, 6, 12].  In fact, a considerable portion of the public gives average or lower marks to K-12 STEM education specifically [3]. This is further illustrated by the fact that only about a quarter of Americans rate K-12 STEM education in the U.S. as above average relative to other developed countries ![25% of Americans consider K-12 STEM education in the U.S. to be at least above average](image5) [9, 10].  However, those with postgraduate degrees in STEM fields hold an even more critical perspective; while they generally have positive views on postsecondary STEM education in the U.S., only a small fraction, about 13%, consider K-12 STEM education to be above average, with a significant 51% believing it to be below average [4, 11].  Therefore, STEM postgraduate degree holders are more critical of K-12 public school STEM education than U.S. adults in general.

European venture capital, despite facing scarcity, has shown remarkable capital efficiency, approximately 70 percent higher than in the US, driven by the selective nature of fewer investors and resulting in lower entry valuations [1].  This period, starting around 2004, marked a turning point for European VC, with continuously improving fundamentals for a decade of venture growth [8].  ![Median pre-money valuations in Europe and the US from 2004 to 2009 are compared across different investment stages](image5).  This improvement is further evidenced by accelerating exit activity, particularly within German VC, indicating enhanced performance in post-bubble vintages [12]. These factors suggest a maturing European venture capital industry with significant potential [11].

To assess uncertainty, this document employs two types of language: confidence and likelihood [9]. Confidence in a finding's validity is judged by considering the type, amount, quality, strength, and consistency of evidence, alongside the degree of expert agreement [9]. Levels of confidence range from very high, which implies strong evidence and high consensus, down to low confidence, indicating inconclusive evidence or expert disagreement [9].  ![Confidence levels are determined by evaluating evidence and expert consensus.](image8).  On the other hand, likelihood language quantifies the probability of an outcome, relying on statistical analysis, model results, or expert judgment [2]. Likelihood is expressed with specific probability ranges, from very unlikely, meaning a less than 1 in 10 chance, to very likely, meaning a greater than 9 in 10 chance [3]. ![Likelihood levels correspond to specific probability ranges of an outcome occurring.](image4). Both confidence and likelihood levels within the Key Findings are grounded in the expert assessment and consensus of the chapter author teams, based on their evaluation of available literature and evidence [11].

Confidence levels are evaluated based on evidence and expert agreement, while likelihood levels are evaluated based on the probability of an outcome.

Americans hold similar views regarding the ethical standards of both the Republican and Democratic parties, with about four-in-ten believing each party has high ethical standards [3, 4].  Interestingly, views on ethical standards are similar to those observed in 2017 [3].  However, public opinion is divided on whether either party possesses high ethical standards; a quarter of the public thinks neither party does [7].

Partisanship strongly influences perceptions of ethical standards. While majorities of both Republicans (66%) and Democrats (64%) consider their own party to have high ethical standards, they are less positive about the opposing party [9]. Independents, particularly, are more inclined to believe that neither party holds high ethical standards compared to partisans [5].  ![Public views are divided on whether the Republican and Democratic parties have high ethical standards, with similar percentages for each party.](image1)

Education level also plays a role in these perceptions. Among individuals with at least a college degree, a notable portion (31%) thinks neither party has high ethical standards [10]. This suggests that higher education may correlate with a more critical view of both parties' ethics.  ![Breakdown of opinions on whether neither party has high ethical standards, one party but not the other, or both, categorized by education level.](image4)

When it comes to being "too extreme," more Americans perceive the Republican Party as such (48%) compared to the Democratic Party (42%), although this view of the Republican party has slightly decreased since June [8]. Partisan divides are also evident in views of extremism, with each party largely seeing the other as "too extreme" [11]. ![Views on whether the Republican party is too extreme among Republican/Lean Republican and Democrat/Lean Democrat groups in May 2018 and August 2017.](image3)

In summary, perceptions of political parties' ethics and extremism are shaped by both education and political affiliation, with partisans showing strong biases towards their own party and education levels potentially influencing a more critical view of party ethics.

Public opinion suggests a close similarity in the perceived ethical standards of the Republican and Democratic parties, with approximately four in ten Americans believing each possesses high ethical standards [1, 4].  ![This image compares public perceptions of the Republican and Democratic parties across three traits: having good policy ideas, having high ethical standards, and being too extreme.](image1).  This perception has remained relatively stable over time [1].  However, when considering the trait of being "too extreme," the Republican Party is viewed more negatively by a slightly larger segment of the public [7].

Education level introduces a nuanced perspective to these ethical assessments.  Individuals with a college degree or higher education are more inclined to believe that neither the Republican nor the Democratic party possesses high ethical standards [3, 12]. ![This chart shows the varying opinions on whether neither, one, or both parties have high ethical standards, categorized by education level.](image4). In contrast, those with less educational attainment are less likely to hold this view of widespread ethical deficiency [12].

Political affiliation heavily influences perceptions of party ethics. Independents are significantly more prone than partisans to assert that neither party operates with high ethical standards [5].  Partisans, while showing some internal critique, are still more inclined to attribute higher ethical standards to their own party [8]. ![This table details the perception of ethical standards among different political affiliations, including Republicans, Democrats, and Independents, along with their leanings.](image2).  Ultimately, a considerable portion of the public expresses a belief that ethical standards are lacking in at least one of the two major political parties [6]. In summary, while ethical standards are rated similarly for both parties, views on extremism are somewhat more critical of the Republican Party, and both education and political affiliation play significant roles in shaping these perceptions.

Public perception indicates a similarity in ethical standards between the Republican and Democratic parties, with roughly equal percentages of Americans expressing skepticism towards both [1].  This sentiment is echoed when considering policy ideas, where the public views both parties with comparable lenses [2].  However, a closer look reveals that educational attainment and political affiliation significantly shape these perceptions.

![This image shows that among college graduates and above, 31% believe neither party has high ethical standards, a higher percentage compared to those with lower education levels.](image5)

Individuals with higher education levels, such as college graduates, are more inclined to believe that neither party upholds high ethical standards [5].  As visualized, a notable portion of college graduates express that "high ethical standards" describe neither the Republican nor the Democratic party, a view less prevalent among those with less formal education [10, 12].

![This image shows that Independents are more likely to believe neither party has high ethical standards compared to Republicans and Democrats.](image5)

Furthermore, political affiliation introduces another layer of complexity. Independents are notably more prone to assert that neither party possesses high ethical standards compared to those who identify with either the Republican or Democratic parties [9]. While partisans are somewhat more charitable towards their own party, the general trend suggests a critical evaluation of ethical standards across the political spectrum [6].

![This image shows that individuals with postgraduate and college degrees tend to favor Democratic candidates over Republican candidates in voting preferences.](image3)

In terms of political preferences, education again emerges as a differentiating factor.  Voters with postgraduate and four-year college degrees exhibit a stronger inclination towards Democratic candidates, highlighting an educational divide in political alignment [8].

In conclusion, perceptions of ethical standards and political party preferences are intricately linked to both education level and political affiliation, with higher education and independent standing correlating with increased skepticism towards the ethical standards of both major parties and higher education levels showing a preference for the Democratic party.

Public opinion regarding Trump's handling of economic policy is somewhat divided, with a narrow majority expressing at least some confidence in his economic decision-making [6, 11].  This confidence has seen a slight increase since earlier periods [12], and extends to specific areas such as negotiating trade agreements with other countries [11].  However, a significant portion of the public still expresses little to no confidence in his economic policies [6].

Conversely, when considering ethical standards, public perception reveals a strong partisan divide. While evaluations of ethical standards are generally low for both major parties [1], the criticism is notably pronounced when directed at Trump's administration.  A substantial majority of Democrats express negative views on the ethical standards of Trump administration officials [9], and even within the Republican party, a considerable segment of moderate and liberal Republicans voice concerns [5]. This contrasts sharply with conservative Republicans, the majority of whom hold positive views on the administration's ethical conduct [5, 9].

The partisan polarization is evident when comparing confidence levels across different groups.  Republicans are significantly more likely to express confidence in Trump across various domains, including economic policy, while Democrats consistently show low confidence [8]. This deep partisan divide highlights the contrasting perceptions of Trump's performance and conduct among different political affiliations, with ethical standards facing particularly strong criticism from Democrats, while economic policy receives mixed but slightly more favorable views from the broader public.  ![Significant partisan divide in perceptions of ethical standards, with Democrats being much more critical than Republicans](image8).

In summary, views on Trump's handling of economic policy are mixed with a slight positive leaning, whereas perceptions of his ethical standards are deeply divided along partisan lines, with Democrats being significantly more critical than Republicans.

Public opinion regarding President Trump's capabilities in handling economic policy and international crises reveals an interesting trend of increasing confidence since the beginning of the year [1].  Notably, public confidence in his handling of international crises has risen from 35% in January to 43% currently, although it was slightly higher at 48% in April [12]. This upward trend is mirrored in economic policy, where confidence has also seen a slight increase [10].

![Public confidence in Trump's ability to handle economic policy and international crises has generally increased since January 2018, as depicted by the upward trends for both categories between January and May 2018.](image3)

However, despite these improvements, overall public confidence remains mixed.  A narrow majority still expresses little to no confidence in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis and make good decisions about economic policy [6, 7].  As detailed in a recent survey, 54% of the public have little to no confidence in his handling of international crises and 46% express similar sentiments regarding his economic policy decisions.

![This image shows that for both "Handle an international crisis" and "Make good decisions about economic policy", the combined percentage of "Not too/Not at all" confident is still higher than "Somewhat & Very" confident.](image1)

Partisan perspectives play a significant role in shaping these opinions.  Republicans, in particular, have shown a marked increase in confidence, especially in Trump's ability to manage international crises, jumping from 73% in January to 84% currently [9].  This surge in Republican confidence aligns with a broader trend where an increasing majority of Republicans now agree with Trump on many or all issues [3].  In contrast, Democrats overwhelmingly disapprove of Trump's conduct [8], and this partisan divide is starkly illustrated when assessing overall job performance.

![This image shows a very large partisan gap in opinions of Trump's job performance, with the vast majority of Democrats rating it as "Poor" while a much smaller percentage of Republicans do so.](image4)

In conclusion, while public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy and international crises has seen a slight increase since January, driven largely by growing Republican support, overall confidence remains mixed and deeply divided along partisan lines.

Public confidence in President Trump's capacity to manage critical areas has shown some interesting shifts.  Notably, there's been an increase in confidence regarding his handling of both international crises and economic policy since earlier in the year [3, 6, 9].  For example, confidence in his ability to navigate international crises has risen from 35% in January to 43% currently, although it was higher at 48% in April of the previous year [4].  Similarly, confidence in his economic policy decisions has also seen an uptick, reaching 53% from a previous 46% [9].

![Public confidence in Trump's ability to handle international crises and make good economic decisions has generally increased from January 2018 to May 2018, with some fluctuations compared to April 2017.](image2)

However, these shifts in confidence are not uniform across the political spectrum.  Republicans, particularly conservative Republicans, are significantly more inclined to view Trump's conduct favorably [1].  A substantial 80% of Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals now express agreement with Trump on many or all issues, a notable increase from 69% in August [10, 12].  While 38% of Republicans overall express liking Trump's conduct, a larger segment, 45%, holds mixed feelings [2].

![Republicans show a high level of agreement with Trump on issues, while Democrats overwhelmingly disagree, as observed in May 2018 and August 2017.](image1)

In stark contrast, Democrats overwhelmingly disapprove of Trump's conduct, with 85% expressing dislike, a sentiment that has remained consistent [8].  This partisan divide is further illustrated when examining overall feelings towards Trump's conduct, where a large majority of Democrats express dislike, while Republicans are more divided between liking and having mixed feelings [image5].

![Democrats predominantly dislike Trump's conduct, while Republicans are more split between liking it and having mixed feelings.](image5)

In conclusion, while public confidence in Trump's abilities in handling international crises and economic policy has generally improved since the beginning of the year,  this confidence is heavily influenced by partisan affiliation, with Republicans showing stronger approval and Democrats maintaining strong disapproval of his conduct.

Public confidence in Donald Trump's capacity to manage critical areas has shown some interesting shifts.  Specifically, regarding international crises, there's been an uptick in confidence since January [10].  This is visually represented in trends where we can see the change over time for handling an international crisis and making good economic decisions. ![Trend of public confidence in Trump on handling international crisis and economic policy over time](image8).  Similarly, when it comes to economic policy, public confidence has also experienced a positive change from earlier in the year [12].  Looking at a breakdown of different capabilities, we can see how handling an international crisis and making economic policy decisions are perceived relative to other areas. ![Comparison of public confidence in Trump's various abilities including handling international crisis and economic policy](image7).  Notably, Republican confidence in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis has grown considerably since January [6].  Overall, while public confidence in several of Trump's abilities has remained stable, there are areas where it has increased, particularly in handling international crises and economic matters [8].

In conclusion, public confidence in Trump's ability to handle both international crises and make sound economic decisions has improved since earlier in the year, with economic policy decisions currently eliciting slightly higher confidence levels.

Americans held varied views on the ethical standards of the Trump administration, with approximately four-in-ten rating them as excellent or good, while a larger percentage found them not good or poor [1].  These ratings were notably lower when compared to previous administrations going back to Ronald Reagan's era ![Ethical ratings of Trump administration are lower compared to past presidents.](image1).

Democrats consistently showed strong disapproval of Trump's conduct, with a large majority expressing dislike [4]. However, criticism wasn't limited to Democrats; even within the Republican party, only a minority explicitly liked Trump's conduct, with a significant portion having mixed feelings [3].  Partisan divisions are evident when examining views among Republicans and Democrats concerning Trump's conduct ![Republicans are more likely to have mixed feelings while Democrats overwhelmingly dislike Trump's conduct.](image6).

Over time, opinions on Trump's conduct and ethical standards have shown some degree of fluctuation within partisan groups.  For example, among Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals, agreement with Trump on issues increased from August 2017 to May 2018 [12], and views on Trump's conduct also shifted slightly during this period ![Change in opinions on Trump between May 2018 and August 2017 among Republicans and Democrats.](image2).  However, public evaluation of Trump's job handling remained largely consistent in recent months, mirroring ratings from the beginning of his presidency [8].

In conclusion, opinions on Trump's conduct and the ethical standards of his administration were deeply divided along partisan lines, with Democrats consistently critical and Republicans showing a mix of support and mixed feelings, and while some fluctuations occurred, overall evaluations remained relatively stable over time.

Public perception indicates that the ethical standards of the Trump administration are notably lower when contrasted with previous administrations, as evaluations reveal a trend where ethical ratings for Trump administration officials lag behind those of past administrations [2]. A considerable portion of the public, $58\%$, rates the ethical standards of the current administration as either not good or poor [7], and these ratings are indeed lower than those recorded for administrations dating back to Ronald Reagan’s era [11].  ![This image shows a bar chart comparing the ethical standards ratings of different presidential administrations, including Trump's, Obama's, G.W. Bush's, Clinton's, and Reagan's, highlighting that Trump's administration receives lower ratings in May 2018 compared to previous administrations at various points in time.](image7)  Despite these low ethical ratings, public approval of Donald Trump's handling of his presidential duties has remained relatively stable in recent months, mirroring the ratings observed at the beginning of his term [3].  It's also observed that disapproval is often more intensely felt, with a significant $42\%$ of the public expressing strong disapproval of Trump's job performance [4].  ![This image displays a breakdown of approval and disapproval ratings for Donald Trump across various demographic groups, including gender, race, age, and education level, illustrating the variations in public sentiment.](image8)  The ethical standards of Trump's administration are rated lower than previous administrations, yet this does not directly correlate with a decline in his consistent job approval ratings.

Americans' views on ethical standards within political parties are notably influenced by their level of education.  Those with higher education are more inclined to believe that neither the Republican nor Democratic party possesses high ethical standards [12].  For instance, about 31% of individuals with a college degree or higher education hold this view. This perspective contrasts with those who have less education; a smaller percentage of individuals with some college experience (26%) or a high school degree or less (20%) believe neither party has high ethical standards [4].

![College graduates are more likely to think neither party has high ethical standards](image6)

Political affiliation also plays a significant role in shaping perceptions of ethical standards and approval ratings.  Independents, for example, are more likely than partisans to say that neither party has high ethical standards [9].  A substantial 65% of independents express negative views about the ethical standards of the Trump administration [7].  This contrasts with partisans, where majorities of both Republicans (66%) and Democrats (64%) describe their own party as having high ethical standards, although this is a somewhat less positive view of their own party [1].

![Independents are more negative about Trump administration's ethical standards](image3)

Furthermore, approval ratings for Donald Trump are significantly divided along political lines, and also intersect with educational demographics [2].  While Republicans overwhelmingly approve of Trump, Democrats largely disapprove, and this divide is evident across different educational levels as shown in the image.

![Trump's approval ratings vary significantly across political and educational groups](image1)

In conclusion, both educational levels and political affiliations are key factors that significantly shape public opinion on ethical standards within political parties and influence approval ratings of political figures like Donald Trump.

Voter reactions to the 2016 presidential election were notably more negative when compared to previous election cycles [4, 5, 8].  Evaluations regarding the conduct of candidates, parties, the press, and pollsters during the campaign were more unfavorable than in any election since 1988 [4], and voters perceived the campaign itself as more negative and less focused on issues compared to past elections [5].  While approximately half of voters expressed happiness with Donald Trump's victory, a level similar to reactions following Barack Obama's 2012 reelection [2, 6], this positive sentiment was less pronounced than it was after Obama's initial election in 2008 [2]. ![Happiness levels regarding election outcomes in 2016 were similar to 2012, but lower than in 2008.](image5).  In fact, a significant 73% of all voters expressed surprise at Trump's victory [3], and many voters reported a mix of emotions, including hopefulness (51%) and pride (36%), along with feelings of unease [9]. ![Voters reported experiencing emotions such as hopefulness, pride, and unease following Trump's election.](image2).  In contrast, emotional responses to Barack Obama's 2008 election were more positive, with a larger percentage of voters feeling hopeful (69%) and a smaller percentage feeling uneasy (35%) [12]. ![Emotional reactions to Obama's election were more positive compared to reactions to Trump's election.](image6).  In summary, voter reactions to the 2016 election were more negative and characterized by mixed emotions, predominantly surprise and hopefulness, contrasting with the more positive reactions observed in earlier elections such as 2008.

The emotional responses to Donald Trump's election in 2016 were markedly different between those who voted for him and those who supported Hillary Clinton.  A significant majority of Trump voters, specifically $96\%$, expressed feelings of hope regarding his election [3], as visually represented by the high percentage in  ![High percentage of Trump voters feeling hopeful](image5).  This positive sentiment extended to pride, with $74\%$ of Trump voters reporting this emotion [3, 7, image5].  Conversely, Clinton voters experienced predominantly negative emotions.

![Negative emotions prevalent among Clinton voters](image3) The most common reaction among Clinton supporters was unease, reported by $90\%$ [12], followed closely by sadness at $77\%$ and fear at $76\%$ [7, 12].  Anger was also a significant emotion, felt by $62\%$ of Clinton voters [12, image3]. Interestingly, the intensity of negative emotions like sadness and anger was even more pronounced among Clinton voters with college degrees [1, 8]. For instance, $85\%$ of college-educated Clinton voters felt sad compared to $70\%$ of those without a degree [1], and $69\%$ of the former group felt angry, versus $56\%$ of the latter [8].

This emotional divide is mirrored in the expectations for Trump's first term.  An overwhelming $97\%$ of Trump voters anticipated a successful first term for him [6, 11], demonstrating strong confidence in his presidency, as shown in ![High confidence among Trump voters regarding Trump's presidency](image6).  In stark contrast, only $15\%$ of Clinton supporters believed Trump would have a successful first term, with a large majority of $76\%$ predicting failure [9].  This level of pessimism among Clinton voters was notably higher than the negativity McCain voters felt towards Obama in 2008, where $39\%$ of McCain voters still anticipated a successful first term for Obama ![Comparison of expected success between Obama and Trump](image1).  Overall, while $56\%$ of voters were optimistic about Trump's first term, this was less positive than the $67\%$ who felt optimistic about Obama's first term in 2008 [10, image7].

In conclusion, Trump voters were overwhelmingly hopeful and confident about his election and upcoming term, while Clinton voters largely felt negative emotions and anticipated an unsuccessful presidency.

Following the contentious election, voter reactions and anticipations for Donald Trump's presidency are markedly divided.  A significant majority of Trump voters, a striking 97%, anticipate a successful first term for him [9], mirroring the optimism Obama voters held in 2008.  This contrasts sharply with Clinton voters, among whom only a small fraction, 15%, foresee success for Trump [10].  ![Trump voters are overwhelmingly hopeful and proud about Trump's election, while Clinton voters express negative emotions](image1).  In fact, the expectation of success among Clinton voters is considerably lower than McCain supporters' expectations for Obama in 2008 [10].

While a majority of Clinton voters, 58%, express a willingness to give Trump a chance to govern [1, 11], a substantial 39% find it impossible to do so due to their perception of his character [1, 11]. This sentiment is visually represented, highlighting the division even within Clinton's voter base regarding giving Trump a chance. ![A significant portion of Clinton voters are unwilling to give Trump a chance due to his perceived character](image3).  Conversely, Trump voters exhibit overwhelming confidence in the kind of president he will be, with 88% expressing confidence and only a small 10% harboring serious concerns [12].  This confidence is clearly illustrated. ![The vast majority of Trump voters are confident in Trump's presidency](image2).

In summary, Trump voters are overwhelmingly optimistic about Trump's first term and confident in his presidency, whereas Clinton voters are largely pessimistic about his success, though a slim majority are willing to give him a chance despite significant reservations about his character.

The priorities for Trump's presidency are viewed quite differently depending on whether you ask a Trump voter or a Clinton voter.  For those who voted for Trump, key issues like healthcare, the economy, and immigration stand out as top priorities [9, 10].  This is visually clear when comparing the percentages of each voter group who prioritize these issues. ![Trump voters prioritize healthcare, economy and immigration more than Clinton voters](image5).  On the other hand, Clinton voters tend to emphasize different aspects, focusing more on "unifying the country" and seeing Trump change his "personal behavior" [6, image5]. This difference in priorities underscores a fundamental divergence in what each group hopes to see from Trump's time in office.

This difference extends to how clearly each group perceives Trump's overall vision for the country.  A significant majority of Clinton voters express that Trump's goals are "not very clear" [8]. ![Clinton voters find Trump's goals unclear](image4).  This contrasts sharply with Trump voters, the vast majority of whom believe they have a "good idea of where Trump wants to lead the country" [8].  This clarity gap suggests that Clinton voters may be struggling to understand or agree with the direction Trump intends to take the nation [1].

Ultimately, these contrasting priorities and perceptions of vision reflect deeper sentiments about Trump's leadership.  While many Clinton voters harbor "serious concerns about what kind of president Trump will be" [image8] and some feel they cannot support him due to his personal conduct [image1], Trump voters express confidence in his ability to handle important issues [2].

In conclusion, the differing priorities between Trump and Clinton voters reveal a significant divide in their expectations for his presidency and their fundamental views on his leadership and vision.

Trump voters show considerable faith in Trump’s ability to handle the economy, but their confidence is less pronounced when it comes to foreign policy [1].  Specifically, about half of Trump voters express a great deal of confidence in his foreign policy decisions, while a large portion still maintains at least a fair amount of confidence [1]. In stark contrast, Clinton voters overwhelmingly lack confidence in Trump’s foreign policy approach, with a significant majority expressing either not too much or no confidence at all [9].  ![Trump voters have more confidence than Clinton voters in Trump's handling of foreign policy](image7).  This difference in confidence extends across various issues, but is particularly pronounced in areas like foreign policy where the partisan divide is clear [12].

Expectations for race relations after Trump's election also reveal a sharp divergence between voter groups. A large majority of Clinton voters anticipate a decline in race relations, whereas Trump voters are more optimistic, with half expecting improvement and a significant portion believing there will be no change [7, 11].  ![Clinton voters largely expect race relations to worsen, while Trump voters anticipate improvement or no change](image6). This stark contrast highlights the deep divisions in post-election perceptions among different voter bases [5].

In conclusion, Trump voters exhibit notably higher confidence in Trump’s foreign policy abilities and hold more optimistic views on race relations post-election compared to Clinton voters, who express significant skepticism and pessimism in both domains.

Many voters expressed pessimism about race relations under Trump's presidency, with almost half anticipating a worsening situation [1].  ![Many voters believed race relations would worsen under Trump's presidency](image8).  Notably, a significant majority of Clinton voters expected race relations to deteriorate [4].  However, half of Trump's voters were optimistic about improvements in race relations [10]. This contrasted with the greater optimism observed after Obama's election in 2008, when more voters anticipated improvements in race relations [7]. ![Comparison of expectations for race relations in 2016 and 2008](image6).  In terms of political cooperation, few anticipated improvements following Trump's election [12].  While nearly half of Trump voters felt positive about partisan relations improving, overall optimism was less pronounced than it was after Obama's election, and Clinton voters were less optimistic than McCain voters had been in 2008 [6, 9].

Overall, Trump voters were more confident than Clinton voters that Trump's presidency would improve both race relations and political cooperation.

Voter expectations following the 2016 election revealed a notable pessimism regarding race relations, with almost half of all voters anticipating a worsening in this area [9].  This sentiment was particularly strong among Clinton voters, where an overwhelming majority believed race relations would deteriorate under Trump's presidency [2, 9]. In fact, a striking 84% of Clinton voters predicted a decline in race relations  ![84% of Clinton voters predicted a decline in race relations](image5).  Conversely, when considering partisan relations, the outlook was more varied, although not overwhelmingly positive.  A significant proportion of voters anticipated no improvement, or even a worsening, in relations between parties in the coming year [11].  While some Trump supporters held onto optimism for better partisan relations, this was slightly less pronounced than the optimism seen among Obama voters in 2008 [6, 10]. Overall, a considerable segment of voters expected partisan relations to remain largely unchanged  ![Expectations for partisan relations were mixed, with a considerable segment expecting relations to remain largely unchanged](image4). Adding another layer to this perspective is the notion that having enthusiastic supporters might not always translate to political progress, as suggested by the idea that "supporters means less gets done" ![Enthusiastic supporters may paradoxically hinder political progress](image1), implying that strong partisan support could potentially lead to gridlock rather than cooperation. The partisan divide indeed widened after the 2016 election in comparison to 2008 [4].  In conclusion, voters were more pessimistic about race relations than optimistic after the 2016 election, and their expectations for partisan relations were also muted, coupled with a concern that strong supporter bases could impede political progress.

Over time, Republican voters have consistently shown a preference for a more conservative direction for their party [9].  This preference is visually represented, showing a clear majority favoring a conservative stance across various periods. ![Republicans favor conservative direction over time.](image1).  In fact, currently, a significant majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning voters, specifically $60\%$, advocate for the GOP to become more conservative, while only $36\%$ prefer a more moderate approach [9].  This preference for a conservative direction has remained relatively stable in recent years [9].

Conversely, Democratic voters have shown an increasing inclination towards a more liberal direction for their party, especially when compared to past election cycles [3, 10].  This trend is also depicted visually, illustrating the growing support for a liberal stance among Democrats. ![Democrats favor liberal direction over time.](image2).  Currently, Democrats are almost evenly split, with $49\%$ favoring a more liberal direction and $47\%$ preferring a moderate one [3]. However, the proportion of Democrats desiring a more liberal direction has significantly increased from just $38\%$ two years prior to the 2016 election and only about a third following Obama's presidential victories [10].

In reaction to the 2016 election results, where the Republican Party maintained control of Congress, voter reactions were mixed [4].  Approximately half of all voters expressed happiness with this outcome, while nearly as many were unhappy [4].  However, this happiness is heavily divided along partisan lines.  A large majority of Trump voters ($94\%$) were happy with the GOP retaining congressional control, whereas an even larger majority of Clinton supporters ($87\%$) were unhappy [2].  This partisan divide in reactions to the 2016 election outcome is starkly illustrated. ![Voters are divided on happiness about Republican congressional control.](image3).

The political orientations of both Democratic and Republican voters have shown shifts towards more ideologically distinct directions, and their reactions to the 2016 election outcomes were highly partisan.

In 2016, a notable contrast emerged in voter expectations compared to 2008 regarding political leaders collaborating with the newly elected president.  Democrats in 2016 showed significantly less enthusiasm for their leaders to cooperate with Donald Trump than Republicans had for working with Barack Obama in 2008 [1].  This divergence is highlighted by the fact that nearly two-thirds of Democrats in 2016 preferred their leaders to "stand up to Donald Trump" even at the cost of legislative progress [12].  ![Democrats in 2016 were considerably more inclined to have their leaders oppose Trump compared to Republicans' stance on Obama in 2008.](image8)

Looking back to 2008, the sentiment was different.  A considerable 59% of Republicans and Republican leaners were in favor of GOP leaders collaborating with Barack Obama, in contrast to only 36% who wanted them to oppose him [2].  Moreover, a substantial proportion of both Obama and McCain voters, around 78% and 76% respectively, advocated for Democratic and Republican leaders to work together, even if it meant disappointing their own supporters [6].  ![Comparison of voter preferences for political leaders' approach towards newly elected presidents Obama and Trump in 2008 and 2016 respectively.](image3)

However, in 2016, the political climate shifted, with a strong partisan divide influencing voter expectations. While over half of Republicans still hoped for Trump to work with Democratic leaders [5], the overwhelming desire among Democrats was for their leaders to challenge Trump, marking a significant departure from the bipartisan настроения observed in 2008.  Voter expectations and sentiments regarding political leaders working with or against newly elected presidents differed significantly between 2008 and 2016, with a marked decrease in bipartisan hope for cooperation in 2016, especially amongst Democrats.

The 2016 presidential election was marked by a strong sense of negativity among voters, with an overwhelming majority perceiving it as more negative than previous campaigns [12].  Specifically, 92% of voters felt there was an increase in "mudslinging" compared to past elections, a significant jump from earlier years ![A large majority of voters perceived more mudslinging in the 2016 election.](image1). This widespread perception of negativity is also reflected in how voters graded the conduct of various entities involved in the election.  Both political parties, for example, received historically low grades for their campaign conduct, with failing grades reaching the highest point since 1988 [3].  Similarly, the press and pollsters were also judged harshly, receiving low grades from voters who were critical of their pre-election surveys [7].  Even voters themselves did not escape this critical assessment, receiving their lowest grades since 1996, suggesting a broad dissatisfaction with the entire electoral process [11]. This overall negative sentiment is further illustrated by the generally low average grades assigned to political parties, candidates, the press, pollsters, and even voters themselves, indicating a pervasive sense of disapproval across the board ![Average grades given to parties, candidates, press, pollsters, and voters were generally low.](image4).  This heightened negativity in the 2016 election represents a trend of increasing negative campaigning over recent election cycles ![The trend of voters perceiving campaigns as more negative has generally increased over time, reaching a peak in 2016.](image7). Consequently, the pervasive negativity of the 2016 election campaign is directly linked to voters' negative perceptions and poor evaluations of political entities and their own role in the process.

The emotional landscape following Donald Trump's unexpected victory in the 2016 election was complex and varied, deeply influenced by voters' affiliations.  Many voters were initially taken aback by the outcome, with a significant majority, including both Clinton and Trump supporters, expressing surprise [1]. This initial shock is evident in the immediate reactions, as "surprised" and "shocked" were frequently mentioned words, even among Trump's own voters [2].  Trump voters often summarized their feelings with "happy" [2], and overwhelmingly reported feeling "hopeful" and "proud" about his election [5].  Conversely, Clinton voters' reactions were markedly different, dominated by negative emotions. "Shocked" topped their list, followed by "disappointed" and "disgusted," reflecting a sense of dismay and disbelief [10].  The contrast is stark when comparing the word clouds summarizing emotional responses for each group, showing "Happy" and "Hopeful" for Trump voters against "Shocked" and "Disappointed" for Clinton voters ![Word clouds showing contrasting emotional reactions of Trump and Clinton voters, with positive emotions dominating for Trump voters and negative emotions for Clinton voters](image2).

Across the broader electorate, "uneasy" emerged as a prevalent feeling, alongside "hopeful," indicating a divided sentiment about the future under Trump's presidency [3, 6, 8].  A considerable portion of voters felt "uneasy," "sad," and "scared," while a slightly larger group leaned towards "hopeful" [6].  This mixed emotional response occurred in the context of a campaign widely perceived as exceptionally negative, with an overwhelming majority of voters believing there was more "mudslinging" than in previous elections [7, 9, image6].  Furthermore, campaign actors, including both Republican and Democratic parties, received low performance grades from voters, highlighting widespread dissatisfaction with the conduct of the election process ![Bar chart showing average grades given to Trump, Clinton, Republican Party, Democratic Party, the press, pollsters, and voters, with most receiving C or D grades](image1).

In conclusion, emotional reactions to Trump's 2016 victory were highly polarized, with Trump voters experiencing predominantly positive emotions like hope and happiness, while Clinton voters felt shock, disappointment, and unease; this emotional divide occurred against a backdrop of perceived negative campaigning and general dissatisfaction with the conduct of the election.

The emotional responses to Donald Trump's victory reveal a stark contrast between voter groups, yet also highlight a shared sentiment. While a significant portion of both Trump and Clinton voters expressed surprise at the election outcome [2, 3], as shown by the varying degrees of surprise among all voters, Trump voters, and Clinton voters in the survey data ![Voters from both sides were largely surprised by Trump's victory](image6), the emotional aftermath differed greatly. Trump supporters frequently used the word "happy" to describe their feelings, alongside "surprised" or "shocked,"  and many also felt "hopeful" and "proud" following his win [7, 9]. These positive sentiments, such as "Happy," "Relieved," and "Elated," are clearly listed for Trump voters in post-election surveys ![Trump voters primarily expressed positive emotions like happiness and relief, alongside surprise](image8).

Conversely, Clinton voters predominantly reacted with negative emotions; "shocked" was the most common descriptor, followed by "disappointed" and "disgusted," also expressing "surprise or disbelief" [10]. This contrasts sharply with the range of negative emotions, including "Shocked," "Disappointed," and "Disgusted," reported by Clinton voters in surveys ![Clinton voters primarily expressed negative emotions such as shock, disappointment, and disgust, alongside surprise](image8).  The widespread surprise, especially among Clinton voters ($87\%$) [2, 3], indicates that pre-election expectations, particularly for Clinton supporters, did not anticipate a Trump victory, leading to strong and often negative emotional reactions post-election. In conclusion, emotional reactions to Trump's victory highlight a divide between happy and hopeful Trump voters and shocked and disappointed Clinton voters, unified by a shared sense of surprise at the unexpected election outcome.

Despite the shared sense of surprise regarding the election outcome, with a majority of both Trump and Clinton voters expressing it [1, 9], distinct emotional landscapes emerged following Donald Trump's victory.  ![Surprise level of voters](image1).  While many Trump voters described their feelings with positive terms like "Happy", "Hopeful" and "Proud" ![Feelings of Trump and Clinton voters towards Trump's victory](image3), and even words like "Relieved" or "Elated" [image6], Clinton voters' sentiments leaned heavily towards the negative, encompassing feelings of "Uneasy", "Sad", "Scared", and "Angry"  ![Feelings of Trump and Clinton voters towards Trump's victory](image3), with many using words such as "Shocked", "Disappointed", and "Disgusted" [image6].  Interestingly, while unhappiness among the losing candidate's voters is typical, it was more pronounced for Clinton's supporters in 2016 compared to McCain's supporters in 2008 [11], as seen in reactions to Obama's 2008 victory  ![Comparison of unhappiness between Clinton and McCain voters](image4).  However, a point of convergence exists in their outlook on future female leadership; a significant majority from both sides anticipate a female president within their lifetime [4].

In summary, while both groups were surprised by Trump's victory, their emotional responses and expectations for a female president starkly contrast, except for the shared long-term expectation of a female president.

Public perception regarding the government's counter-terrorism measures has shifted notably, revealing a growing concern that these policies may not be sufficiently robust to safeguard the nation.  This marks a change from earlier sentiments, particularly after revelations about surveillance programs, when concerns about civil liberties being overly restricted were more prominent [12].  Currently, a larger segment of Americans expresses apprehension that anti-terrorism policies are inadequate rather than excessively restrictive [1].  ![Americans are now more concerned that anti-terror policies have not gone far enough to protect the country.](image1). This shift is underscored by declining approval ratings for the government's endeavors in diminishing terrorist threats, which have reached their lowest point since the aftermath of the September 11th attacks [2].  This decline in positive evaluations is observed across the political spectrum, though varying in degree among different partisan groups [3].  Notably, assessments from conservative Republicans have become significantly more critical [11], and while a majority of Democrats still rate government efforts positively, this majority has shrunk [3].  ![Republicans are more likely to express concerns on terrorism.](image2).  Age also plays a role in these perceptions, with older Americans exhibiting a tendency to rate the government's efforts more negatively compared to their younger counterparts [4, 6].  In conclusion, there's a discernible trend towards increased public worry about the government's anti-terrorism policies not being sufficiently impactful, coupled with a decrease in positive evaluations of these efforts, influenced by both political affiliation and age.

Americans' views on the government's counter-terrorism efforts are notably shaped by age. Older Americans are more critical, with a majority of those 50 and older expressing dissatisfaction with the government's performance in reducing terrorist threats [4].  This contrasts with younger adults aged 18-29, where a larger percentage believe the government is doing well [4].  ![Older Americans are more likely to think the government is not doing well in reducing terrorist threat](image7). This age divide extends to concerns about government policies; younger adults are more concerned about the government going too far in restricting civil liberties, while older groups prioritize stronger protective measures [7, 9].

Political ideology also significantly colors these perceptions.  There's a clear partisan divide in how government efforts are viewed. Assessments of government actions against terrorism have become more negative across the political spectrum since early 2015 [3]. Notably, Republicans now show much lower approval of government efforts compared to earlier periods, and this decline is also observed among Democrats and Independents, although Democrats still remain the most positive group [3]. ![Government approval ratings for handling terrorism differ significantly between Republicans, Democrats and Independents](image4).  Despite these shifts, a larger percentage of Americans overall express greater concern that anti-terror policies haven't gone far enough to protect the country rather than going too far in restricting civil liberties [2].

Over time, concerns about civil liberties have decreased since 2013, particularly after revelations about NSA surveillance programs [8].  However, recent trends indicate a growing concern that government policies may not be aggressive enough in combating terrorism [2].  This shift is evident across different age groups, although the intensity of concern and the balance between security and civil liberties remain influenced by both age and political leaning. Ultimately, age and political ideology are key factors shaping perceptions of government efforts against terrorism, with older and more conservative individuals often expressing greater concern about security and government effectiveness, while younger and more liberal individuals tend to emphasize civil liberties and express more nuanced views on government performance.

In 2015, evaluations of the government's efforts in reducing terrorist threats varied across age groups. Older Americans, particularly those aged 50 and above, tended to express more negative views on the government's performance, with a majority in this demographic feeling that the government was not doing well in reducing the terrorist threat [6].  This contrasts with younger adults aged 18-29, among whom a larger proportion rated the government's performance positively ![This image shows the percentage of different age groups rating government performance in reducing terrorist threats as "Very/Fairly well" and "Not too/Not at all well".](image2).

Interestingly, when considering concerns about anti-terrorism policies, a different perspective emerges across age groups.  Adults under 30 were notably divided in their concerns, almost equally split between worrying that policies excessively restricted civil liberties and that they didn't go far enough to ensure national protection [7]. However, older age groups, especially those 65 and older, showed a stronger inclination towards prioritizing security over civil liberties, expressing greater concern that policies were insufficient to protect the country ![This image shows the percentage of different age groups who think anti-terror policies "Too far in restricting civ libs" versus "Not far enough to protect US".](image5).

In summary, older age groups in 2015 were more critical of the government's anti-terrorism efforts and were also more inclined to believe that anti-terrorism policies did not go far enough to protect the country, while younger adults were more divided in both their assessment of government performance and their concerns about the balance between security and civil liberties.

Americans are increasingly expressing concern that government anti-terrorism policies do not adequately protect the country [4], with this sentiment mirroring levels observed shortly after the 2010 Detroit airliner attack [1].
