Chameleon outperforms Gemini and GPT-4V in fulfilling 'How-to' tasks, while enhanced versions of Gemini and GPT-4V show improved but still varied performance.

Step-Back + RAG demonstrates different error profiles across datasets. On TimeQA, it significantly rectifies baseline errors, turning around $39.9\%$ of incorrect predictions, but also introduces errors in $5.6\%$ of previously correct predictions [11]. Furthermore, Step-Back + RAG improves upon raw RAG by correcting $21.6\%$ of its errors, while adding new errors in only $6.3\%$ of cases [11]. In contrast, for StrategyQA, Step-Back + RAG converts $15.4\%$ of baseline model's wrong predictions into correct ones and causes a $6.1\%$ error rate in previously correct answers [5].  When compared to RAG alone, Step-Back + RAG corrects $12.7\%$ of RAG's errors and introduces new errors at a rate of $4.4\%$ [5].

![Visual representation of error analysis, showing categories like 'Both Wrong', 'Baseline Wrong RAG Wrong', 'Step-Back + RAG Wrong', 'Both Right'](image8)

The error analysis indicates that Step-Back + RAG is more effective at correcting baseline errors in TimeQA compared to StrategyQA, but also introduces slightly higher error rates when refining RAG outputs on TimeQA. Overall, Step-Back + RAG exhibits varied error correction and introduction rates depending on the dataset.

The SnapNTell dataset distinguishes itself by focusing on fine-grained entities and knowledge-intensive question-answer pairs [1].  Unlike existing datasets that often lack entity specificity [2], SnapNTell is designed for entity-centric knowledge-based VQA [2, 6], aiming to evaluate models on their ability to recognize entities and provide detailed, entity-specific knowledge [6, 10].  This benchmark incorporates a diverse range of real-world entities, categorized into 22 groups such as landmark, painting, and food, ensuring a broad spectrum of entities encountered in daily life [5].

![SnapNTell dataset includes 22 categories with the number of entities in each category](image5)

Compared to other datasets like ViQuAE and Encyclopedic VQA, SnapNTell offers a greater variety of categories, a larger number of unique entities, and a higher volume of QA pairs [9].  Furthermore, the dataset is structured with 10 images per entity, and its questions are designed to be anonymous, ensuring they are not biased towards specific knowledge bases [9].  SnapNTell dataset encompasses a wide range of categorized entities, each paired with images and explicit entity names in the answers, emphasizing knowledge-intensive responses over simple binary answers [10].

![SnapNTell dataset has more categories, unique entities, QA pairs and images compared to ViQuAE and Encyclopedic VQA](image7)

SnapNTell stands out by including a wide array of fine-grained entities with representative images and explicit entity names in the answer sets, requiring knowledge-intensive responses, which moves beyond simplistic binary answers [7]. Datasets like OK-VQA and AOK-VQA have broadened knowledge categories and question complexity [3, 8], but SnapNTell uniquely focuses on detailed entity-specific understanding and generation of knowledgeable responses [4].

![SnapNTell dataset requires knowledge-intensive answer compared to GQA and OK-VQA](image1)

In summary, the SnapNTell dataset is designed to surpass other VQA datasets by offering a broader range of categories, a larger number of entities, and a focus on knowledge-intensive questions and answers centered around fine-grained entities.

The DSC model demonstrates superior performance across a variety of datasets, consistently achieving the highest F1 scores. This is highlighted by its performance on both positive and negative datasets, where DSC significantly outperforms DL, especially in imbalanced datasets, showing its robustness [6].  For tasks like paraphrase identification, DSC paired with BERT and XLNet consistently yields top F1 scores on datasets like MRPC and QQP, outperforming other loss functions like FL and DL  ![DSC achieves the highest F1 scores on MRPC and QQP datasets](image8). In Chinese datasets for tasks such as POS tagging, DSC significantly improves upon the BERT-tagger baseline, achieving state-of-the-art results on CTB5, CTB6, and UD1.4 datasets, surpassing other loss functions in robustness for data imbalance issues  ![BERT+DSC achieves the highest F1 scores on Chinese datasets CTB5, CTB6, and UD1.4](image2). On English datasets for POS tagging like WSJ and English Tweets, BERT-Tagger with DSC consistently achieves the highest F1 scores, indicating its effectiveness across languages and dataset types ![BERT-Tagger+DSC achieves the highest F1 scores on English WSJ and English Tweets datasets](image4). When applied to Named Entity Recognition (NER) tasks, DSC again stands out, outperforming BERT-MRC on datasets such as CoNLL2003, OntoNotes5.0, MSRA, and OntoNotes4.0, setting new state-of-the-art performance levels [12] ![BERT-MRC+DSC achieves the highest F1 scores on English CoNLL 2003 dataset](image6). Across different MRC tasks and datasets like SQuAD v1.1, v2.0, and QuoRef, DSC consistently provides a significant performance boost when used with BERT or XLNet, surpassing XLNet's performance alone [2] ![XLNet+DSC achieves the highest F1 scores on SQuAD v1.1, SQuAD v2.0 and QuoRef datasets](image1).

In conclusion, the DSC model achieves the highest F1 score across multiple datasets.

For Named Entity Recognition tasks, the performance of BERT-MRC models has been evaluated across datasets like English CoNLL 2003 and English OntoNotes 5.0 [4].  On the English CoNLL 2003 dataset, the original BERT-MRC model achieves a Precision of 92.33, Recall of 94.61, and an F1-score of 93.04, whereas the DSC loss variation improves these metrics to a Precision of 93.41, Recall of 93.25, and a higher F1-score of 93.33, marking a +0.29 increase in F1-score ![Table showing performance comparison of BERT-MRC variations on the English CoNLL 2003 dataset](image7). Similarly, for the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, the base BERT-MRC model shows a Precision of 92.98, Recall of 89.95, and F1-score of 91.11, which are enhanced by DSC loss to a Precision of 91.59, Recall of 92.56, and a superior F1-score of 92.07, reflecting a +0.96 improvement in F1-score ![Table detailing the performance gains of BERT-MRC variations on the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset](image2).  Across both datasets, the application of DSC loss consistently leads to performance improvements over the baseline BERT-MRC model [5].  In conclusion, BERT-MRC model variations, especially those incorporating DSC loss, demonstrate enhanced performance on both English CoNLL 2003 and English OntoNotes 5.0 datasets.

The DS-Picklist model demonstrates superior performance in dialog state tracking.  This is evident as it achieves a joint accuracy of 53.30%, outperforming models like BERT-DST, BERT-DST-Picklist and ToD-BERT in this metric ![DS-Picklist achieves a joint accuracy of 53.30%, which is higher than BERT-DST, BERT-DST-Picklist, and ToD-BERT in joint accuracy](image5). Further supporting its effectiveness, DS-Picklist also achieves the highest average slot accuracy at 97.40% when compared to DS-Span and DS-DST models ![DS-Picklist achieves the highest average slot accuracy at 97.40% compared to DS-Span and DS-DST in slot accuracy](image7).  The models described as "ours" achieve top performance and state-of-the-art results, indicating the overall effectiveness of the DS-model family, especially DS-Picklist, which leverages a full ontology [2, 8].  These models, including DS-Picklist, consistently outperform BERT-DST and ToD-BERT, showcasing the benefit of strong interactions between dialog context and domain-slot pairs in their design [9, 11]. In conclusion, DS-Picklist stands out as the model achieving the highest joint accuracy and average slot accuracy.

The DeClarE (Full) model's performance is gauged using error metrics such as Mean Squared Error (MSE) for credibility regression tasks and Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) for confidence score evaluations [4, 5, 11]. When assessing credibility regression on the NewsTrust dataset, DeClarE (Full) achieves a notably low MSE of 0.29, outperforming other models like CNN-text, CCRF+SVR, LSTM-text, Distant Supervision and even its own plain configuration, demonstrating a substantial 17% reduction in MSE compared to the best baselines  ![Comparison of MSE values for different models on the NewsTrust dataset](image5) [12]. For credibility classification on the SemEval dataset, while specific error values are presented in comparison to other models, DeClarE (Full) is highlighted as outperforming all other approaches overall, suggesting its effectiveness in minimizing prediction errors in credibility assessment tasks, even though the RMSE value of DeClarE (Full) is numerically higher than some other models in the table. ![Comparison of RMSE and Accuracy values for different models on the SemEval dataset](image3) [5].

In summary, DeClarE (Full) generally shows superior performance compared to other configurations when evaluated using error metrics like MSE and RMSE.

Our approach demonstrates notable advancements in performance when compared to other methodologies across both the LANI and CHAI datasets [1]. Specifically, on the LANI navigation task, our method surpasses CHAPLOT 18 by a margin of 5% in task completion accuracy, and both our approach and CHAPLOT 18 outperform MISRA 17 [1].  This performance landscape is clearly illustrated in the comparative metrics displayed ![Performance table comparing 'Our Approach' with baselines and other methods on LANI and CHAI datasets using metrics like SD, TC, and MA.](image1), where 'Our Approach' shows superior task completion (TC) and stop distance (SD) scores on LANI.  For the CHAI dataset, while methods like CHAPLOT 18 and MISRA 17 struggle to learn effectively, our approach still manages to show improvements in stop distance (SD) [1], although manipulation accuracy (MA) remains a challenge across all models as shown in ![Performance comparison table showing the metrics SD, TC, and MA for LANI and CHAI datasets across different methods, including 'Our Approach' and baselines.](image8).  In essence, 'Our Approach' generally exhibits enhanced performance metrics on LANI and CHAI datasets relative to other methods, particularly in navigation tasks, though challenges persist in complex manipulation scenarios within CHAI.

The 'Ours' model demonstrates a clear advancement in performance when compared to existing Named Entity Recognition (NER) models, establishing a new state-of-the-art result [8].  This improvement is evident across various performance metrics. For instance, when evaluated on training data, the 'Ours' model achieves superior accuracy (Acc.), macro-averaged F1 (MaFl), and micro-averaged F1 (MiFl) scores compared to 'Attentive NER' as shown in the performance comparison. ![Training Data Performance](image1).

Furthermore, when juxtaposed with models like 'AttentiveNER++', 'AFET', and 'LNR', 'Ours' consistently exhibits higher scores in Accuracy, Macro-F1, and Micro-F1 metrics.  This is clearly illustrated in the comparative results. ![Acc. Ma-F1 Mi-F1](image2).  Specifically, in a direct comparison with 'AttentiveNER' on development and test datasets, 'Our Model' shows a higher Mean Reciprocal Rank (MRR) and F1 score on both datasets, indicating a better ability to rank correct types and overall improved performance. ![Dev Test](image8).  While there's a trade-off where 'Ours' experiences a decrease in precision, it gains significantly in recall compared to 'AttentiveNER', suggesting it's more effective at identifying a broader range of correct entity types [12].

In conclusion, the ‘Ours’ model outperforms other NER models like AttentiveNER, AttentiveNER++, AFET, and LNR in terms of accuracy and F1 scores, establishing a new state-of-the-art in fine-grained NER tasks.

The model achieving a high F1-value in Named Entity Recognition (NER) is the CCNN+WLSTM+CRF model, reaching an F1-value of 91.35 [7, 9]. This is highlighted in the provided table, which compares various models and their performance across NER, chunking, and POS tagging tasks ![Table showing NER, chunking and POS F1-values for different models](image3).  The effectiveness of this model stems from its architecture, which leverages Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) to encode character sequences and Long Short-Term Memory networks (LSTM) to process word sequences, finalized by a Conditional Random Field (CRF) inference layer  ![A general model architecture diagram showing char sequence layer, word sequence layer and inference layer](image5).

The integration of character information significantly enhances model performance, with both LSTM and CNN character sequence encoders providing comparable improvements over models lacking character information [9].  Furthermore, the use of LSTM for word sequences generally outperforms CNN word sequence representations, indicating LSTM's superior ability to capture global features crucial for sequence labeling tasks [9].  Therefore, the combination of character-level CNNs and word-level LSTMs, within a CRF framework, contributes to the high F1-value achieved by the CCNN+WLSTM+CRF model for NER.

In conclusion, the CCNN+WLSTM+CRF model attains the highest F1-value for NER, primarily due to the synergistic effect of character-level CNNs, word-level LSTMs, and CRF inference.

The LSTUR approach, which leverages both long-term preferences and short-term interests of users, demonstrates superior performance in news recommendation compared to baseline methods [6]. This effectiveness is partly attributed to its ability to capture the complex and diverse nature of user interests in news consumption, a nuance that simpler baseline models often miss [6]. You can see from the experimental results that LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con achieve the highest AUC and nDCG@10 values among all compared methods, indicating their effectiveness in news recommendation.

![LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con methods achieve the highest AUC and nDCG@10 values compared to other methods.](image4)

The table above shows a detailed comparison, where LSTUR-ini achieves an AUC of 63.56 and nDCG@10 of 41.37, and LSTUR-con achieves an AUC of 63.47 and nDCG@10 of 41.34, outperforming other methods like GRU, DKN, and CNN [image4]. Both LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con methods, designed to learn long- and short-term user representations, achieve comparable and strong performance [2].  These results confirm that integrating both long-term and short-term user representations is beneficial for accurately understanding user interests and enhancing news recommendation systems [1].

![LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con achieve top AUC and nDCG@10 performance.](image2)

Based on the AUC and nDCG@10 metrics, LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con methods exhibit the best performance for news recommendation.

Training NLP models, while achieving impressive results, comes with a considerable environmental cost due to the energy consumption involved, which translates to significant carbon dioxide emissions [8, 9, 12].  For instance, training BERT on GPUs has been estimated to produce CO₂ emissions roughly equivalent to a trans-American flight [4].  To put this into perspective, consider the annual carbon footprint of an average human life, which is around 11,023 lbs of CO₂ equivalent, or an average American life, which is significantly higher at 36,156 lbs annually, and even a lifetime of car usage produces around 126,000 lbs of CO₂ equivalent, as illustrated in ![Comparison of CO₂ emissions for everyday activities and human lifespans](image5).  The development and training of these models, especially with extensive experimentation and tuning, can dramatically increase these emissions [7, 11]. The energy used in training could potentially be reallocated to more basic needs, like heating homes, highlighting the substantial environmental impact of these computationally intensive tasks [9].  Therefore, the CO₂ emissions from training certain NLP models are comparable to, and in some cases can exceed, the emissions from common everyday activities.

Initially, BERT achieved a high test set accuracy, reaching $77\%$ in its best run, which is surprisingly close to the average untrained human baseline [1]. This performance is achieved by a BERT classifier where the claim and reason are combined into the first text segment. This segment is then paired with each warrant and processed independently, as depicted in the architecture diagram ![The BERT classifier architecture joins claim and reason to form the first text segment, pairs it with each warrant, and processes them independently.](image2). The final layer CLS vector is then passed to a linear layer to obtain logits, and the entire architecture is fine-tuned [3]. The general architecture for these models involves shared parameters learned to classify each warrant independently with the argument, yielding logits [4].  However, when evaluated on an adversarial dataset, BERT's peak performance significantly dropped to $53\%$ [7], with the median test accuracy falling to approximately $50\%$ ![BERT's performance on adversarial test set shows a median of 0.505 and max of 0.533.](image5). In the original test setting, BERT (Large) exhibits a median test accuracy of $0.712$ [6], as shown in the results table ![Table displaying baselines and BERT results, showing BERT Large with a median test accuracy of 0.712.](image3).

The model with the highest test median score is BERT, and its architecture involves processing claim, reason, and warrants independently before passing through a linear layer for classification.

The COMET model demonstrates superior performance compared to baseline models, as evidenced by both automatic and human evaluation metrics. In terms of BLEU-2, COMET achieves a higher score, signifying an improvement in the quality of generated text [1].  This is visually supported by performance metrics, where COMET surpasses other models like 9ENC9DEC and Event2 in BLEU-2 scores. ![COMET outperforms baselines in BLEU-2 score](image8).

Furthermore, human evaluations reveal a statistically significant increase in average performance for COMET over baselines, indicating better event understanding and generation quality as perceived by humans [1].  This consistent performance improvement is observed across various relation types, solidifying COMET's robust understanding and generation capabilities [2].  The average performance metrics showcase COMET's advancement over models such as 9Enc9Dec and different variations of Event2, highlighting its enhanced ability to generate commonsense knowledge that aligns well with human judgment. ![COMET demonstrates higher average performance in human evaluations compared to baselines](image2).  In summary, COMET outperforms other models in both BLEU-2 and average event understanding metrics, showcasing its enhanced capability in commonsense knowledge generation.

Extractive question answering models like BiDAF and FastQA have been evaluated on datasets such as WikiHop and MedHop [6].  Performance comparisons reveal that BiDAF generally surpasses FastQA in both standard and gold chain settings across both datasets, as shown in the provided performance table. ![Table showing the performance of BiDAF and FastQA models under standard and gold chain conditions for WikiHop and MedHop](image3). The "gold chain" condition, where models receive only documents relevant to the answer, significantly improves their performance [9].  This improvement is evident in the accuracy increase for both BiDAF and FastQA when moving from standard to gold chain setups, particularly for BiDAF on WikiHop, reaching up to 81.2% in masked settings, as detailed in the table.  Moreover, research indicates that BiDAF is more effective at utilizing cross-document information compared to FastQA [12], potentially due to BiDAF's architecture which uses iterative conditioning across multiple layers, enhancing its ability to integrate information from various sources [3], [5].

In conclusion, BiDAF generally outperforms FastQA in both standard and gold chain conditions on WikiHop and MedHop datasets, with gold chain conditions improving both models' performance and BiDAF showing a stronger capacity for using cross-document information.

System-level evaluations generally show higher correlations for translation quality metrics. These evaluations often utilize tables to display the performance of various metrics across different language pairs [3, 11]. For French to German language pair, the system-level metric correlations are detailed, revealing that ESIM achieves a notably high correlation [9].

![Table showing system-level metric correlations for de-fr and fr-de language pairs, highlighting ESIM’s correlation for fr-de](image4)

ESIM metric demonstrates the highest correlation with human assessments for the fr-de language pair.

Positional encodings are crucial components in the transformer architecture of DETR, significantly influencing its object detection performance [1]. The architecture incorporates positional encodings at every attention layer within both the encoder and decoder, as depicted in the model overview ![DETR architecture with encoder, decoder and positional encoding](image1).  Different configurations of these encodings lead to notable variations in Average Precision (AP). For instance, removing spatial positional encodings entirely results in a substantial drop in AP, whereas using them only in the decoder causes a minor decrease [8].  Experiments with various combinations, including fixed sine and learned encodings, reveal that output positional encodings are indispensable, while spatial positional encodings, when passed to attention layers, yield better results compared to input-only configurations ![Positional encoding configurations and their corresponding AP scores](image2). The performance is also influenced by loss components like classification and GIoU loss, as seen in ablation studies, where variations in these loss terms affect the final AP achieved by the model ![Loss components Class and GIoU in DETR and AP results](image7). In summary, different positional encoding strategies and loss component choices critically determine the object detection accuracy, as reflected in the Average Precision metrics of the DETR-DC5 model.

ProgramFC demonstrates enhanced fact-checking interpretability by employing explicit programs, aiding in human understanding and debugging, unlike end-to-end models [2].  Reasoning programs also improve evidence retrieval from knowledge sources, as evidenced by ProgramFC's iterative step-by-step BM25 retriever outperforming the one-step BM25 retriever, particularly on datasets like HOVER 4-hop [3, 8]. This is visually supported by performance metrics across HOVER datasets in retrieval recall, where ProgramFC significantly surpasses one-step retrieval. ![ProgramFC's iterative retrieval notably improves recall compared to one-step retrieval](image8).

The effectiveness of program-guided reasoning is particularly pronounced with smaller language models. Performance results indicate that while end-to-end FLAN-T5 model performance decreases with smaller model sizes, ProgramFC maintains a more stable performance trend.  Remarkably, ProgramFC using FLAN-T5-small achieves comparable performance to the much larger FLAN-T5-XXL for complex 4-hop claims [6].  A visual comparison of F1 scores across different model sizes for HOVER datasets further illustrates this point, showing ProgramFC's consistent performance relative to FLAN-T5 as model size varies. ![ProgramFC maintains performance better than FLAN-T5 as model size decreases](image5).  Looking at overall performance, across various datasets like HOVER (2-hop, 3-hop, 4-hop) and FEVEROUS-S, ProgramFC consistently achieves better F1 scores than baseline models, including FLAN-T5, in both gold and open settings, as detailed in comprehensive performance tables. ![ProgramFC outperforms FLAN-T5 and other baselines across various datasets and hop counts](image1).

In summary, ProgramFC consistently outperforms FLAN-T5, especially for complex claims and with smaller models, and exhibits superior evidence retrieval recall due to its program-guided reasoning approach.

ProgramFC demonstrates a notable advantage in fact-checking by decomposing complex claims into simpler steps, leading to more accurate reasoning compared to directly verifying claims with models like FLAN-T5 [5]. This decomposition strategy proves especially effective when dealing with intricate reasoning tasks, as evidenced by a significant improvement for 4-hop claims [5].  The retrieval of relevant evidence is also enhanced through ProgramFC's reasoning programs, outperforming one-step retrieval methods by iteratively refining searches based on the reasoning process  [3, 12].  ![ProgramFC's iterative retrieval significantly improves recall compared to one-step retrieval, especially for complex claims.](image1).

Compared to end-to-end models, ProgramFC offers improved interpretability due to its explicit reasoning programs, aiding in human understanding and debugging [6]. However, when examining error types, it's observed that semantic errors, particularly structural errors, become more prevalent as claim complexity increases, indicating challenges in generating appropriate reasoning strategies for long-chain reasoning [11].  ![Semantic errors, especially structural ones, become a dominant error type as the complexity of claims increases for ProgramFC.](image7).

Interestingly, ProgramFC's program-guided reasoning is particularly beneficial for smaller language models. While the performance of end-to-end FLAN-T5 models decreases significantly with smaller sizes, ProgramFC maintains more consistent performance across different model sizes [7].  ![ProgramFC shows more consistent performance across different model sizes compared to FLAN-T5, highlighting its effectiveness even with smaller models.](image3).  In comparison to other models across various datasets, ProgramFC generally achieves competitive results, often outperforming baselines and approaching the performance of larger models in complex fact-checking scenarios, as seen in evaluations on HOVER and FEVEROUS datasets [8].  ![ProgramFC generally performs competitively with other models on fact-checking tasks, particularly showing strength in complex scenarios.](image8).  While chain-of-thought prompting can sometimes outperform ProgramFC on simpler tasks, ProgramFC shows better performance on more complex, multi-hop reasoning tasks [10].  ![ProgramFC and other models' performance on HOVER and FEVEROUS datasets, showing ProgramFC's competitive standing.](image6).

In summary, ProgramFC excels in complex fact-checking tasks through its decomposition approach and program-guided reasoning, especially benefiting smaller models and improving retrieval, but it faces challenges in generating correct reasoning structures for highly complex claims, leading to semantic errors.

Fact-checking models reveal interesting performance trends when dealing with claims of varying complexity.  Specifically, the ProgramFC model demonstrates increasing effectiveness as the reasoning depth required to verify claims grows, outperforming baselines by a larger margin for three-hop and four-hop claims compared to two-hop claims on the HOVER dataset [4].  This suggests that ProgramFC is particularly well-suited for complex, multi-step reasoning tasks.

![ProgramFC's effectiveness increases with reasoning depth, especially for 3-hop and 4-hop claims compared to baselines.](image1)

However, even with models like ProgramFC, the HOVER dataset presents a significant challenge, with most models achieving only marginally better than random guessing in terms of Macro-F1 score [7].  Despite this overall difficulty, a trend of improved performance is observed as the number of reasoning hops increases, indicating that models can leverage step-by-step reasoning more effectively for complex claims [7]. Chain-of-thought prompting, for instance, improves performance compared to direct prompting, emphasizing the value of structured reasoning processes [7].  The types of errors made by ProgramFC also shift with increasing claim complexity. Semantic errors become more prominent in programs generated for more complex claims, particularly structural errors, suggesting a growing difficulty in devising appropriate reasoning strategies for long chains of reasoning [11].

![Semantic errors, especially structural errors, become more prevalent as claim complexity increases in ProgramFC.](image4)

While ProgramFC shows promise in enhancing the interpretability of fact-checking through explicit reasoning programs [8], error analysis reveals that incorrect program execution, often stemming from failures in question answering or fact-checking modules, is a significant source of errors, especially for 2-hop claims [5].  The balance between model capability, learning efficiency, and interpretability is a key consideration in the design of such models [3].

![Model performance on HOVER and FEVEROUS datasets across different hop counts.](image3)

In summary, as the number of reasoning hops increases in datasets like HOVER and FEVEROUS, model performance generally improves, but error types shift towards more complex semantic and structural errors, highlighting the challenges in handling increasingly intricate claims.

The 'hard-to-contrast' strategy is designed to overcome the cold start problem in active learning, demonstrating superior performance compared to other querying strategies across various datasets [8, 3]. In datasets like PathMNIST, OrganAM NIST, and BloodMNIST, 'hard-to-contrast' significantly outperforms random selection and other active querying methods [3, 6].  As visualized in performance graphs comparing different initial query strategies, a hard-to-contrast initial query strategy (red lines) excels over others in every active learning cycle, specifically on PathMNIST ![Hard-to-contrast initial query strategy outperforms others on PathMNIST in every active learning cycle](image1).  Similarly, on Organ aM NIST, hard-to-contrast data (red lines) consistently outperforms other initial queries throughout active learning cycles, reinforcing its consistent advantage ![Hard-to-contrast data consistently outperforms other initial queries on OrganAMNIST in active learning](image5).

Across PathMNIST, Organ AM NIST, and BloodMNIST, 'hard-to-contrast' not only surpasses random selection but also other active querying approaches, achieving notably higher performance metrics [3, 6]. This is supported by quantitative data presenting performance metrics for various strategies across different datasets ![Table showing performance metrics of different strategies on PathMNIST, OrganAMNIST, BloodMNIST, and CIFAR-10-LT](image2). The initial query selected by 'hard-to-contrast' plays a crucial role, as the performance in the initial cycle is strongly correlated with performance in subsequent cycles [2, 5, 11].  Furthermore, AUC comparisons across datasets, including PathMNIST, OrganAMNIST, BloodMNIST, and CIFAR-10-LT, also illustrate the superior performance of the hard-to-contrast strategy over alternatives ![AUC comparison of hard-to-contrast strategy against other strategies across multiple datasets](image3). The 'hard-to-contrast' strategy, being label-free, efficiently identifies and selects hard-to-contrast data, leading to more effective models and substantially improved outcomes relative to random selection [3].

The 'hard-to-contrast' strategy consistently outperforms other querying strategies and significantly influences initial query selection by focusing on hard-to-contrast data, leading to enhanced active learning performance across diverse datasets.

Prompt construction significantly impacts the performance of Large Language Models (LLMs) in information extraction tasks [7]. To ensure optimal results, variations in prompt design, specifically instruction format and demonstration selection, were meticulously investigated, as illustrated in Figure 3 ![Figure 3 shows the impact of instruction format, demonstration number, and demonstration selection on the F1 score for ChatGPT and Codex.](image7).  Figure 3 reveals that diverse instruction strategies yield comparable performance for both ChatGPT and Codex. However, the demonstration selection strategy is crucial, with sentence embedding-based retrieval proving particularly effective [7]. In conclusion, while instruction format has a limited impact, the demonstration selection strategy significantly influences the performance of ChatGPT and Codex.

The SciTAB dataset is designed to evaluate scientific fact-checking, moving beyond simpler benchmarks by incorporating real-world scientific claims and table-based evidence [11].  This necessitates a multifaceted and complex range of reasoning types [10], demanding a nuanced approach to verification [1].  These reasoning types include atomic steps such as *simple lookup*, *comparison*, and *closed-domain knowledge* [10, image6].  For example, verifying a claim may require understanding that "Prod." corresponds to "Productivity" from the table caption, illustrating *closed-domain knowledge*, and recognizing "random chance" as 50%, which is *commonsense knowledge*  ![The image shows an example of claim verification, highlighting different reasoning steps such as closed-domain knowledge and commonsense knowledge.](image1).  *Numerical reasoning* is also frequently needed, such as calculating the difference between percentages to verify claims [4, 6].  Furthermore, the complexity of SciTAB is highlighted by the number of reasoning steps needed, with some claims requiring up to 11 steps for verification  ![The image shows a bar chart illustrating the distribution of reasoning steps required for claim verification, with some claims needing up to 11 steps.](image4).  Challenges in verifying claims within SciTAB are diverse, including errors in calculations and approximations, as well as dealing with claims that are only partially correct [5].  Claims labeled as "Not Enough Information" (NEI) often present challenges due to insufficient evidence within the table or a lack of necessary background or *open-domain knowledge* [8] ![The image shows a table listing refuted reasons and NEI reasons, highlighting challenges such as incorrect calculations, wrong approximations, and insufficient evidence.](image8).  Therefore, verifying claims in the SciTAB dataset most commonly involves diverse reasoning types, encountering challenges such as calculation errors, approximation inaccuracies, and information insufficiency.

The SciTab dataset incorporates a variety of reasoning functions to assess the capabilities of models in scientific fact-checking, highlighting the intricate nature of reasoning required [6].  Among these functions, **simple lookup** and **comparison** are utilized most frequently, indicating a substantial portion of tasks involve direct information retrieval and basic numerical comparisons ![Simple lookup and comparison are the most common functions, representing a large portion of reasoning operations within SciTab](image7).  The dataset's complexity is further amplified not only by the diversity of these functions but also by the number of reasoning steps needed, as demonstrated by the distribution of reasoning steps involved [Image 3], suggesting that claims often require multi-faceted reasoning processes.  Furthermore, challenges like table grounding and dealing with ambiguous claims contribute to the difficulty, establishing SciTab as a demanding benchmark for evaluating reasoning within scientific contexts [7].  In conclusion, SciTab dataset employs a range of reasoning functions with varying usage proportions, from prevalent lookups to less frequent complex operations, and the need for multiple reasoning steps, alongside challenges like grounding and ambiguity, collectively contribute to the complex reasoning demands it poses.

The SciTab dataset incorporates a variety of reasoning types, each contributing uniquely to the complexity of scientific fact-checking. Function names, which represent these reasoning types, include operations like simple lookup, comparison, and subtraction, each designed to address different facets of claim verification within tables.  ![Function names like "Simple lookup" and "Comparison" constitute a significant portion of the reasoning types, reflecting the diverse analytical requirements within the SciTab dataset.](image6)  These operations are critical for navigating the nuances of scientific data presented in tabular form.

The distribution of reasoning steps further illustrates the dataset's complexity, showing that claims can require varying numbers of analytical procedures to verify.  ![The distribution of reasoning steps in SciTab indicates that claims necessitate a range of analytical depths, from single-step verifications to more complex, multi-step reasoning.](image2) This variability highlights the dataset's capacity to evaluate models across different cognitive demands.

Error analysis reveals key challenges in processing SciTab data. Grounding errors, where programs misinterpret data-cell associations, and ambiguity errors, arising from vague scientific claims, are prominent issues. [8]  These are compounded by calculation and program errors, illustrating the multifaceted nature of mistakes in automated fact-checking.  ![Error type analysis indicates that grounding and ambiguity are significant challenges in SciTab, pointing to difficulties in data association and claim interpretation.](image5) Furthermore, refuted claims often stem from incorrect calculations or approximations, while claims labeled as 'Not Enough Information' frequently lack sufficient table evidence or necessary background knowledge. [6, 12] ![Refuted claim reasons highlight calculation errors and approximation inaccuracies, whereas NEI claims often suffer from insufficient evidence or a lack of domain-specific knowledge.](image3)

In conclusion, the SciTab dataset encompasses a rich spectrum of reasoning types with varied step distributions, leading to a range of errors predominantly characterized by grounding, ambiguity, and knowledge gaps, reflecting the inherent complexities of scientific fact-checking.

The SciTab dataset exhibits a diverse range of reasons for refuted claims, moving beyond simple negation found in other datasets like Sci-Fact [10].  Specifically, a significant portion of refuted claims in SciTab are due to incorrect calculation results, wrong approximation words, and claims being only partially correct [10].  These complexities highlight the dataset's reflection of real-world scientific claim verification challenges [10].  Reasons for refuted claims and their proportions are further detailed, showing that calculation errors are a key factor, alongside issues like approximation and partially correct claims  ![Refuted claim reasons include calculation errors and approximation issues](image7).

Despite these detailed annotations and the dataset's nuanced nature, current open-source Large Language Models (LLMs) generally struggle with SciTab, showing a considerable performance gap compared to humans [2].  Even the best-performing open-source models achieve only moderate improvements over random guessing, falling far short of human annotator accuracy [2].  Interestingly, table-based LLMs do not necessarily outperform models pre-trained on text alone, possibly due to the unique structure of scientific tables compared to typical table corpora used in pre-training [8]. Evaluations are conducted in both zero-shot and in-context settings, where models are tested without or with limited in-domain examples respectively [1].  The performance of various models, including both open-source and closed-source options like GPT-4, in zero-shot and in-context scenarios for both 2-class and 3-class classification, reveals the ongoing challenges in achieving robust scientific fact-checking with LLMs ![Performance of different LLMs across zero-shot and in-context settings](image5).

The primary reasons for refuted claims in the SciTab dataset include calculation errors, approximation inaccuracies, and partially correct statements, and current LLMs, even in in-context settings, demonstrate limited proficiency in accurately fact-checking these claims compared to human performance.

The SciTAB dataset presents unique challenges in scientific fact-checking, particularly in the classification of refuted and Not Enough Information (NEI) claims. Refuted claims in SciTAB are not simply negations but exhibit a greater diversity, stemming from reasons such as incorrect calculation results, incorrect approximation words, and claims being partially right [3].  These diverse reasons are visually summarized, highlighting that calculation errors account for a significant portion (41.7%), followed by approximation errors (33.3%) and partially correct claims (10.0%) as reasons for refutation. ![Refuted claims are often due to calculation errors, approximation inaccuracies, or partial correctness](image6).

NEI claims also display diverse reasoning patterns, with the most common features being insufficient evidence within the table and a lack of necessary background knowledge [5].  Further reasons for NEI include the absence of closed-domain knowledge, vague pronouns within the claim, and instances where additional information beyond the table is required for verification [5].  These varied reasons for NEI claims, including insufficient evidence (33.3%) and lack of open-domain knowledge (25.0%), contribute to the complexity of the dataset. ![NEI claims often lack sufficient table evidence or domain knowledge](image6).

This complexity significantly impacts the performance of models in zero-shot 3-class classification.  Models generally perform worse in the 3-class setting compared to the 2-class setting, indicating the difficulty in handling the NEI class [10].  This is evident in the performance metrics, where models like Vicuna-7B achieve 63.62 in 2-class but only 32.47 in 3-class settings, and FLAN-T5-XL shows 52.41 in 2-class and 38.05 in 3-class. ![Model performance is notably lower in 3-class classification compared to 2-class](image1).  Specifically, InstructGPT tends to classify supported and refuted claims as NEI, indicating a lack of confidence, while GPT-4 often miscategorizes NEI claims as either supported or refuted, showing overconfidence. ![InstructGPT is less confident and GPT-4 is overconfident in predicting NEI claims](image7).

In summary, the primary reasons for refuted claims in SciTAB include calculation and approximation errors along with claims being partially correct, while NEI claims are mainly due to insufficient evidence and knowledge gaps; these complexities lead to diminished model performance in zero-shot 3-class classification, particularly in accurately identifying NEI claims.

InstructGPT and GPT-4, both closed-source Large Language Models (LLMs), have been evaluated on the SCITAB dataset, a benchmark for scientific fact-checking [7]. In the zero-shot 3-class classification setting, GPT-4 demonstrates superior performance compared to InstructGPT [10].  This performance difference is evident when observing their Macro-F1 scores where GPT-4 achieves 64.80, while InstructGPT's performance is lower, as detailed in the provided benchmark results ![Performance comparison of various models including InstructGPT and GPT-4](image1).

However, analyzing their error patterns reveals distinct characteristics. Confusion matrices for both models in the 3-class setting indicate that both struggle with the "Not Enough Information" (NEI) class [6]. InstructGPT tends to be "less confident," frequently misclassifying supported and refuted claims as NEI. In contrast, GPT-4 exhibits "overconfidence," often incorrectly categorizing NEI claims as either supported or refuted [6]. This difference in confidence and error distribution is visually represented in their respective confusion matrices ![Confusion matrices for InstructGPT and GPT-4, showing different error distributions](image8).

Several error types contribute to these performance differences, particularly in the challenging context of scientific fact-checking. Error analysis on SCITAB highlights grounding errors, ambiguity errors, calculation errors, and program errors as key challenges [5].  Indeed, the difficulty in accurately referencing specific cells in tables (grounding errors) and handling ambiguous scientific claims are unique challenges posed by SCITAB [5]. These error types are further categorized to understand the proportions of different errors in program-based methods ![Proportion of different error types in program-based methods](image3). Ultimately, while GPT-4 outperforms InstructGPT, both models face challenges in accurately predicting the NEI class and handling the complexities of scientific fact-checking within the SCITAB dataset.

In conclusion, GPT-4 outperforms InstructGPT in zero-shot 3-class classification on SCITAB, but both models show distinct error patterns, struggling particularly with NEI classification and facing challenges related to grounding and ambiguous scientific claims.

In zero-shot 3-class classification, both InstructGPT and GPT-4 encounter difficulties, particularly in accurately predicting the NEI (Not Enough Information) class [1].  ![Confusion matrices illustrate the label distribution for InstructGPT and GPT-4, highlighting their challenges in NEI class prediction.](image3)  Notably, InstructGPT displays a tendency to be "less confident," frequently categorizing supported and refuted claims as NEI. Conversely, GPT-4 demonstrates "over confidence," often misclassifying NEI claims as either supported or refuted [1]. Despite these challenges in the nuanced NEI class, GPT-4 generally achieves better performance compared to open source Large Language Models [6]. This difficulty in distinguishing between 'refuted' and 'NEI' claims contributes to a noticeable decrease in performance in the 3-class setting compared to the 2-class setting, potentially diminishing model confidence and causing a shift in predictions towards 'NEI' [10]. Error analysis reveals that grounding errors and ambiguity in claims pose significant challenges within this dataset [12]. These errors, categorized as grounding, ambiguity, calculation, and program errors, contribute to incorrect predictions [8]. ![A table outlines error types and their estimated proportions, such as grounding, ambiguity, calculation, and program errors.](image8)  The performance differences and error types suggest that InstructGPT tends towards underconfidence and uncertainty, while GPT-4, although more performant overall, is prone to overconfidence and misclassification of nuanced or ambiguous claims.

In zero-shot 3-class classification, both InstructGPT and GPT-4 encounter difficulties with Not Enough Information (NEI) claims, but their challenges manifest differently [5, 6]. InstructGPT tends to be "less confident," often misclassifying supported and refuted claims as NEI, suggesting a pattern of avoiding definitive judgments when faced with uncertainty [5].  ![InstructGPT tends to classify supported and refuted claims as NEI due to a lack of confidence](image7). This contrasts with GPT-4, which exhibits "overconfidence," frequently miscategorizing NEI claims as either supported or refuted [5].  ![GPT-4 often incorrectly classifies NEI claims as supported or refuted due to overconfidence](image7). This overconfidence in GPT-4 leads to incorrectly assigning a veracity label even when the claim is unverifiable within the given table context [5, 9]. The fundamental challenge lies in distinguishing verifiable from unverifiable claims, a task that proves difficult even for human annotators and is amplified in the zero-shot setting where models lack specific training examples [6, 7]. In essence, InstructGPT struggles with confidence, leaning towards NEI as a safer but often incorrect prediction, while GPT-4 errs on the side of overconfidence, forcing a supported or refuted label onto claims that lack sufficient evidence [5].

The performance of GPT2-XL and GPT-J models varies across different datasets, as observed in experiments using in-context learning (ICL) across several text classification benchmarks [11].  When considering speed improvements, GPT-J demonstrates a more pronounced acceleration effect compared to GPT2-XL, suggesting greater potential for application in larger language models [9]. This is visually represented in speed-up ratios, where GPT-J consistently outperforms GPT2-XL across datasets like SST-2, TREC, AGNews and EmoC [Image7].

Further analysis into classification accuracies can be gained by examining confusion. For instance, when analyzing category confusion, models like GPT2-XL display varying levels of confusion between categories, especially on datasets like TREC [5]. Predicted confusion scores correlate strongly with actual model confusion, indicating that ICL errors tend to occur in categories with similar label anchors [12]. This is supported by confusion matrices that visualize the predicted confusion between categories such as 'Description' and 'Entity' [Image5] and the actual confusion [Image8]. The 'Confusion' metric accurately identifies highly confusing cases, demonstrating that classification inaccuracies are linked to the similarity of label anchors between categories [12].

In conclusion, GPT-J generally exhibits better speed-up ratios than GPT2-XL, and confusion matrices reveal that classification accuracy in both models is influenced by the degree of category confusion, particularly arising from similar label anchors.

Otter showcases exceptional multi-modal perception and reasoning capabilities, as rigorously evaluated using the MMAGIBench framework, which assesses diverse tasks such as scene and object recognition, OCR, and reasoning across attributes, relations, and future predictions [3, 4].  The model achieves the strongest performance in ChatGPT evaluations within MMAGIBench, surpassing other vision-language models [11]. This superior performance in perception and reasoning is visually represented in benchmark comparisons. ![Otter achieves a high score in Perception and Reasoning benchmark.](image2) Furthermore, when specifically compared to Video Chat GP T on video understanding benchmarks like MSVD and MSRVTT within MMAGIBench, Otter exhibits a clear performance advantage [9].  ![Otter outperforms VideoChatGPT on MSVD and MSRVTT benchmarks.](image4) In few-shot in-context learning, particularly on the COCO caption dataset, Otter also demonstrates remarkable capabilities, significantly outperforming Open Flamingo in various few-shot settings [1, 11]. This improvement over Open Flamingo in COCO captioning can be observed across different few-shot scenarios. ![Otter shows superior performance over OpenFlamingo in COCO caption few-shot evaluations.](image4)

In both MMAGIBench and COCO caption few-shot evaluations, Otter demonstrates superior performance compared to other vision-language models.

Llama 2-Chat models demonstrate a strong safety profile when compared to other open-source models and even perform on par with some closed-source alternatives in terms of safety benchmarks [7].  In evaluations, Llama 2-Chat exhibits a comparable or lower overall violation percentage across different model sizes relative to models like ChatGPT and Falcon, and superior safety compared to MPT and Vicuna [8].  ![Llama 2-Chat models demonstrate lower violation percentages compared to other models.](image1) This visual representation highlights that Llama 2 models generally achieve lower violation percentages, indicating a safer performance.

Notably, multi-turn conversations tend to increase the likelihood of unsafe responses across various models; however, Llama 2-Chat continues to perform competitively in these scenarios [2].  This robust safety performance is attributed to specific training methodologies, including the incorporation of safety-specific data annotation and tuning, alongside red-teaming and iterative evaluations [7].  The training process, visualized as a loop involving human feedback and reward models, directly refines the model's safety [image6]. This iterative process of retraining with human feedback and safety reward models is crucial for enhancing the safety features of Llama 2-Chat.

Furthermore, the inclusion of more safety data during the Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) phase demonstrably improves Llama 2-Chat's ability to respond safely to unsafe prompts [3].  As more safety data is integrated, the model becomes more adept at refusing to generate offensive content and exhibits more conservative behavior when encountering sensitive terms, even within safe contexts [3].  This is further illustrated in another view of violation percentages where Llama 2 models maintain a lower violation rate compared to other models [image5]. This reinforces the earlier point about Llama 2-Chat's enhanced safety performance relative to its peers.

In conclusion, Llama 2-Chat models achieve competitive safety performance through rigorous training processes that include safety-focused data and RLHF, resulting in models that are generally safer than many open-source alternatives and comparable to some closed-source models.

The development of LLaMA 2 considered its environmental impact, with estimations of carbon emissions from pre-training meticulously calculated [5].  The total carbon emission for training the LLaMA 2 family of models is estimated to be 539 tCO2eq, an amount that was completely offset by Meta’s sustainability initiatives [7].  This dedication to environmental responsibility is coupled with the intention of the open release strategy to prevent other organizations from needing to repeat these pre-training costs, contributing to global resource conservation [7].  The carbon footprint varies across different model sizes within the LLaMA 2 family, as detailed in the training emission data. ![Table summarizing the training time, power consumption, and carbon emissions for different LLaMA 2 model sizes](image8). In terms of performance, LLaMA 2 exhibits significant advancements over its predecessor, LLaMA 1, particularly the 70B model which shows notable improvements on benchmarks like MMLU and BBH [6].  Compared to other open-source models such as MPT and Falcon, LLaMA 2 often demonstrates superior performance across a range of benchmarks [6].  For example, Llama 2 70B model surpasses all open-source models in overall performance [6].  When juxtaposed with closed-source models, LLaMA 2 70B approaches the performance levels of GPT-3.5 on tasks like MMLU and GSM8K, and even matches or exceeds the capabilities of PaLM (540B) on numerous benchmarks, although it still lags behind more advanced models like GPT-4 and PaLM-2-L [9]. The comparative benchmark results highlight LLaMA 2's strong standing against both open and closed-source models in various evaluations. ![Benchmark comparison of LLaMA 2, GPT models, and PaLM on various tasks](image1). LLaMA 2 models offer a balance of environmentally conscious development and competitive performance relative to other models.

Llama 2 models have shown a competitive edge over other open-source language models and are even comparable to some closed-source models in several aspects [2].  Notably, Llama 2 marks an improvement from its earlier version, Llama 1, with substantial gains in performance on benchmarks like MMLU and BBH, especially with the 70B model [3].  This is visually represented in ![Llama 2 70B model's benchmark performance compared to other open-source models](image4), which indicates Llama 2 70B's leadership among open-source options.  Compared to models like Falcon and MPT, Llama 2 generally performs better across different benchmarks, though specific code-related benchmarks may vary [3].  A key strength of Llama 2-Chat models is their enhanced truthfulness and significantly reduced toxicity compared to the base Llama 2 models, achieving the lowest toxicity among the models compared [5, 6].  As illustrated in ![Llama 2-Chat demonstrates superior truthfulness and minimal toxicity compared to other models](image5), these fine-tuned models excel in safety-related metrics.  However, when benchmarked against leading closed-source models like GPT-4 and PaLM-2-L, Llama 2 70B still has room for improvement, particularly in coding tasks, despite nearing GPT-3.5's performance on some benchmarks and outperforming PaLM (540B) on others [11, 12, image6].  This comparison is shown in ![Llama 2 70B's benchmark performance against top closed-source models like GPT and PaLM](image6).  To conclude, Llama 2 models exhibit strong performance, particularly in truthfulness and low toxicity, when compared to other models, yet they show a slight weakness in coding benchmarks against top-tier closed-source models.

The removal of knowledge elements significantly impacts citation metrics. As demonstrated, removing required knowledge notably reduces both citation precision and recall, although it minimally affects correctness [9]. This decline is further illustrated in the experimental results, where precision, recall, and F1-Score all decrease as more knowledge is removed from the knowledge graph ![Table showing metrics decrease as removed knowledge increases](image2).  However, under the "Conscious Incompetence" setting, a different trend emerges. Recall remains relatively stable, while precision and F1-Score show an upward trend as more knowledge is identified as absent from the knowledge graph ![Graph showing precision and F1-score increase, recall stable](image1). This suggests that when the model is aware of its knowledge limitations, it can more accurately pinpoint and utilize the available knowledge, even as the knowledge base becomes less comprehensive [10].

In essence, the degradation of precision and recall with general knowledge removal indicates a vulnerability in models when faced with incomplete information. Conversely, the "Conscious Incompetence" setting enhances the model's ability to discern and adapt to knowledge gaps, leading to improved precision and stable recall in scenarios with increasing knowledge scarcity. Ultimately, these changes highlight the importance of equipping language models with mechanisms to recognize and handle situations where knowledge is lacking, thereby improving their reliability and citation quality in real-world applications.

Initially, increasing the number of demonstration samples leads to a marked improvement in performance, although this enhancement diminishes as the number of samples increases beyond a certain point [1].  This is visually supported by Figure 6, which displays the trend of Micro-F1 score improvement with an increasing number of demonstration samples, particularly at the lower end of the sample range ![Micro-F1 score increases with more demonstration samples initially, then plateaus](image1). Furthermore, the inclusion of logical constraints in the instructions given to Large Language Models (LLMs) yields consistent improvements in performance, especially when used in conjunction with a greater number of demonstrations [1].  Figure 2 highlights the fact that models working on the MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets exhibit substantial Micro-F1 score increases when logical constraints are incorporated, as evidenced by the comparison across different settings ![Model performance on MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank improves with logical constraints](image3).  In fact, employing logical constraints with a smaller set of demonstrations can even surpass the performance of prompts that rely solely on a larger number of demonstrations [1]. Broadly, the incorporation of relevant logic into LLM instructions proves to be highly beneficial for enhancing performance in reasoning tasks [8].  Therefore, both logical constraints and demonstration samples are effective in boosting model performance on the MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets; however, logical constraints tend to offer more consistent and significant improvements, particularly when combined with a moderate number of demonstration examples.

Logical constraints and post-processing are two distinct strategies employed to mitigate logical inconsistencies in Large Language Models (LLMs).  Incorporating logical constraints, especially through retrieval-based approaches, demonstrably reduces logical inconsistency and enhances overall performance in tasks such as event relation extraction [1].  This method improves performance by explicitly teaching LLMs logical boundaries [2].  However, while post-processing can guarantee the elimination of logical conflicts, achieving a Logical Inconsistency (LI) of $0\%$, it may come at the cost of answer quality, potentially deviating from the ground truth due to random selection and potentially requiring extensive operations [1].  As shown in the result table, models using post-processing achieve zero LI but often exhibit lower Micro-F1 scores compared to those using retrieved logical constraints across both MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets, exemplified by the 'w. post-processing' rows consistently having 0% LI but lower Micro-F1 than 'w. retrieved logical constraints' rows in both tasks. ![Post-processing achieves zero logical inconsistency but generally lower performance compared to retrieval-based logical constraints](image1). This observation is further supported when comparing different approaches across various models in MAVEN-ERE, Causal-TimeBank and Proof Writer, where post-processing, while effective at removing inconsistencies, does not lead to the highest performance [image3]. In contrast, directly integrating logical constraints into LLM instructions is generally more effective than applying post-processing after results are generated [7]. Ultimately, while post-processing can eliminate logical inconsistencies, leveraging logical constraints during the generation process appears to be a more balanced approach for enhancing both logical consistency and overall performance in LLMs. In conclusion, logical constraints offer a more effective balance between reducing logical inconsistency and maintaining model performance compared to post-processing methods across MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets.

The MMMU benchmark is structured across six core disciplines, with Business constituting 14% and Health & Medicine 17% of the question distribution, as visualized in the discipline overview ![Comprehensive Disciplines](image1).  Within the Business discipline, questions are categorized into subjects such as Accounting, Economics, Finance, Management, and Marketing.  Similarly, Health & Medicine encompasses subjects like Basic Medical Science, Clinical Medicine, Diagnostics, Pharmacy, and Public Health, providing a detailed subject breakdown as shown ![Art & Design (11%)](image6). This distribution is part of a comprehensive benchmark designed to assess expert-level multimodal understanding across various college-level subjects [3, 7, 8].  Questions within Business and Health & Medicine are diverse, reflecting the breadth of topics within these disciplines.

The MMMU dataset is designed to assess multimodal understanding and reasoning at a college level, featuring a range of question difficulties [8, 2].  The distribution of these difficulties within the benchmark is characterized by a higher proportion of medium-difficulty questions.  Specifically, approximately 45% of the questions are classified as medium, while easy and hard questions constitute about 28% and 27% respectively, as depicted in the benchmark statistics. ![The difficulty distribution of the MMMU dataset is approximately 28% easy, 45% medium, and 27% hard.](image3)  These questions are distributed across six core disciplines: Art & Design, Business, Science, Health & Medicine, Humanities & Social Science, and Tech & Engineering [2].  Each discipline encompasses various subjects and subfields, ensuring a broad coverage of college-level knowledge. The proportion of questions from each discipline varies, reflecting the diverse nature of the benchmark.  For example, Science and Tech & Engineering represent larger portions of the dataset compared to Humanities & Social Science or Art & Design. ![The dataset includes six disciplines: Art & Design, Business, Science, Health & Medicine, Humanities & Social Science, and Tech & Engineering, with percentage breakdowns for each.](image2)  Thus, the MMMU benchmark incorporates a balanced distribution of question difficulty across its comprehensive range of academic disciplines.

The MMMU dataset is designed to broadly assess multimodal understanding across a range of academic fields, incorporating six core disciplines such as Art & Design, Business, Science, Health & Medicine, Humanities & Social Science, and Tech & Engineering [6, 9, 12]. This breadth is intentional, as the selection of subjects was guided by the prevalence of visual inputs in conveying crucial information within these fields [3].  The benchmark encompasses 30 distinct subjects and 183 subfields, ensuring a wide coverage of college-level knowledge [6, 9, 12].  Reflecting this disciplinary diversity, MMMU incorporates 30 different image types, ranging from advertisements to complex diagrams, to mirror the variety of visual formats encountered in these diverse subjects [1, 2].  For instance, questions in Art & Design may utilize sheet music as visual input, while Health & Medicine questions might feature body scans like MRIs, and Tech & Engineering questions often include circuit diagrams ![Example questions from various disciplines illustrating different image types such as sheet music, medical scans, charts, and circuit diagrams](image3). This deliberate inclusion of heterogeneous image types ensures that the benchmark effectively evaluates a model's perceptual abilities across the diverse visual information relevant to each discipline [6].  The dataset comprises a total of 11,550 questions, distributed across disciplines with Science and Tech & Engineering having a larger proportion, as visually represented [image1, image5, image7].  The questions are predominantly multiple-choice, but also include open-ended questions and questions requiring explanations, with almost all questions incorporating images, frequently interleaved with text to mimic real-world scenarios [image1, image5].  Therefore, the distribution of questions across different disciplines in the MMMU dataset directly dictates the variety of image types and question formats employed within the benchmark.

The MMMU benchmark is meticulously designed to evaluate expert-level multimodal understanding across a wide range of disciplines [3].  This benchmark aims for a broad coverage of knowledge, extending beyond common sense to encompass college-level expertise across 30 diverse subjects [4, 8].  ![MMMU benchmark aims for broad knowledge coverage](image2) This breadth is visually represented through the diverse range of image types and subject areas it covers [2]. The dataset strategically samples across six core disciplines, ensuring a wide spectrum of knowledge domains are tested [3, 8, 12].  ![MMMU covers 30 subjects across 6 disciplines](image5) These disciplines include Art & Design, Business, Science, Health & Medicine, Humanities & Social Science, and Tech & Engineering, each further divided into numerous subfields [3, 5]. MMMU is not only broad but also deep, requiring deliberate reasoning and expert-level skills rather than just common knowledge [4, 8].  ![MMMU emphasizes expert-level reasoning and knowledge](image3) The distribution of subject areas within the MMMU dataset is thus carefully structured to align with its goals of assessing both breadth of knowledge and depth of reasoning capabilities in multimodal models.

The subject distribution in the MMMU dataset effectively mirrors its intended breadth and depth coverage in reasoning and knowledge.

The MMMU benchmark stands out by specifically targeting expert-level multimodal understanding, requiring both sophisticated visual perception and deep reasoning with subject-specific knowledge [1]. This contrasts with many existing benchmarks that often focus on more basic perception abilities and common sense knowledge [10, 6].  MMMU is designed to assess college-level multi-discipline understanding and reasoning, drawing its questions from college exams and textbooks across six broad disciplines: Art & Design, Business, Science, Health & Medicine, Humanities & Social Science, and Tech & Engineering [2].

Compared to prior benchmarks which are often limited in image format and focused on daily knowledge, MMMU encompasses 30 diverse image types, including complex diagrams, tables, charts, and medical images, alongside natural photographs and paintings [6]. This breadth in image types tests the perceptual capabilities of large multimodal models more rigorously.  Furthermore, MMMU's questions necessitate deliberate reasoning with college-level subject knowledge, going beyond simple commonsense or temporal reasoning required by other benchmarks [6].  ![MMMU is designed with high reasoning depth and knowledge breadth compared to other benchmarks.](image1)

MMMU is a comprehensive benchmark comprising 11.5K questions, organized into development, validation, and test sets [4]. The questions are primarily multiple-choice (94.03%) with a smaller portion of open questions (5.97%), and a significant number include explanations (17.62%) [image4].  A vast majority of questions (97.52%) incorporate images, frequently positioned in the middle or end of the question text, and sometimes involve multiple images [image4]. The benchmark covers 30 subjects across 6 disciplines, with a detailed distribution across Engineering (26%), Science (23%), Health & Medicine (17%), Business (14%), Art & Design (11%), and Humanities & Social Science (9%) [image3, image6]. This extensive coverage ensures a broad evaluation of a model's capabilities across diverse fields of knowledge.

In summary, the MMMU benchmark distinguishes itself through its expert-level difficulty, broad subject coverage across diverse disciplines and image types, and its emphasis on deep reasoning and subject-specific knowledge, making it a more challenging and comprehensive evaluation tool compared to many existing multimodal benchmarks.

The MMMU benchmark distinguishes itself from other datasets through its focus on expert-level multimodal understanding and reasoning [4]. Unlike benchmarks that primarily test basic perception and common sense [5, 10], MMMU delves into college-level subject matter across six disciplines and 30 subjects [3, 4], demanding a broader knowledge base.  This breadth is visually represented in the diverse disciplines covered, from Art & Design to Tech & Engineering, as depicted in ![MMMU benchmark covers a wide range of disciplines and subjects.](image7).  Furthermore, MMMU challenges models with questions requiring deliberate reasoning and expert-level domain knowledge, moving beyond simple physical or temporal reasoning seen in other benchmarks [5, 4].  The complexity of reasoning is further emphasized by the benchmark's error analysis, revealing that a significant portion of errors in advanced models like GPT-4V stem from perceptual issues, knowledge gaps, and reasoning flaws [2].

MMMU uniquely incorporates a wide array of 30 image types, including diagrams, tables, charts, and medical images [5, 8], going beyond the limited image formats of prior benchmarks. This heterogeneity in image types, as illustrated by examples ranging from diagrams to medical scans in ![MMMU benchmark uses diverse and heterogeneous image types.](image5), tests the perceptual capabilities of models more rigorously [4]. Moreover, the benchmark features interleaved text and image inputs, necessitating a deeper joint interpretation of both modalities, rather than just basic OCR or captioning [2, 4].  In terms of question format, MMMU primarily utilizes multiple-choice questions, but also includes open questions and questions with explanations, mirroring college-level exams and quizzes [4, Image1].  The statistical breakdown of question types and dataset composition is detailed in ![MMMU benchmark questions are primarily multiple-choice with detailed statistics.](image1).  In essence, MMMU stands out by integrating both depth of reasoning and breadth of knowledge, as conceptually summarized in ![MMMU benchmark is unique in its depth and breadth compared to other datasets.](image6), alongside its sophisticated use of diverse image formats and complex question structures, creating a benchmark that is significantly more challenging and comprehensive than existing datasets [7, 12].

The MMMU benchmark uniquely combines expert-level reasoning with broad college-level knowledge, utilizing diverse image types and complex question formats to provide a more rigorous evaluation than other datasets.

MMMU is specifically designed to test expert-level multimodal understanding, a step beyond benchmarks that focus on more basic perception skills [7]. Unlike previous benchmarks that often rely on common sense or simple reasoning, MMMU challenges models with college-level subject knowledge and necessitates deliberate, complex reasoning [3, 4].  This benchmark distinguishes itself by covering a wide range of subjects and subfields, aiming for a comprehensive assessment of knowledge breadth [8, 10]. ![MMMU benchmark covers comprehensive disciplines like Art & Design, Business, Science, Health & Medicine, Humanities & Social Science, and Tech & Engineering](image3).  Furthermore, MMMU incorporates 30 different image formats, a significant increase compared to the limited image type coverage in earlier benchmarks [3, 8]. This variety in image formats rigorously tests the perceptual capabilities of models across diverse visual inputs [8]. The benchmark's positioning in terms of breadth and depth is clearly visualized, illustrating MMMU's higher demands relative to benchmarks like VQA and ScienceQA. ![MMMU benchmark exhibits greater breadth and depth compared to other benchmarks](image8).  In summary, MMMU stands out from other benchmarks due to its expert-level reasoning depth, broad knowledge coverage, and variety of image types.

GPT-4V exhibits superior proficiency in simpler tasks, achieving a notable success rate of 76.1% in the "Easy" category, significantly outpacing open-source models [11].  However, the performance advantage of GPT-4V diminishes considerably as the tasks become more challenging, especially in the "Hard" category, suggesting a limitation in handling expert-level queries even for advanced models [8, 11, image8 showing model performance across easy, medium and hard difficulty levels].

Across different image categories, GPT-4V consistently outperforms other models. Open-source models demonstrate relatively better performance with frequently encountered image types like Photos and Paintings. Conversely, for less common image formats such as Geometric shapes and Music sheets, all models, including GPT-4V, achieve low scores, indicating a weakness in generalizing to less frequent image types [12, image3 showing model performance across different image types].

Analysis of GPT-4V errors reveals that a significant portion are attributed to perceptual errors, knowledge gaps, and flaws in reasoning processes [7, 10, image7 illustrating distribution of error types]. For instance, in a scenario involving oxygen masks on an airplane, GPT-4V demonstrated a perceptual error by misinterpreting the order of images, despite possessing the correct knowledge and reasoning abilities to answer the question [image1 illustrating a perceptual error example].

Current models, even the most advanced ones like GPT-4V, still encounter considerable challenges in multimodal understanding and reasoning when faced with complex visual inputs and tasks requiring substantial subject matter expertise.

Based on evaluations, the GPT-4V model demonstrates superior performance across various test categories [3]. Evident from the data, in easier tasks, GPT-4V achieves a significantly higher success rate of 76.1% compared to open-source alternatives, highlighting its proficiency in less complex scenarios [10, ![GPT-4V demonstrates high success rate in easy difficulty level.](image5)].  Even as task complexity increases to the 'Medium' category, GPT-4V maintains its lead, achieving 55.6% accuracy, though the performance gap narrows [6, ![GPT-4V leads in medium difficulty category.](image5)]. While the advantage of GPT-4V diminishes further in 'Hard' tasks, indicating a challenge for even advanced models in expert-level queries, its overall performance still stands out [6, ![GPT-4V performance decreases in hard difficulty but still competitive.](image5)].  Comparing its overall accuracy, GPT-4V achieves 55.7%, which, while indicating room for improvement, is notably higher than open-source models that hover around 34% [2, 5, ![GPT-4V overall accuracy is 55.7%.](image5)]. This performance disparity underscores a clear gap between proprietary models like GPT-4V and currently available open-source models [9, ![Open-source models have lower accuracy than GPT-4V.](image1)].  In summary, GPT-4V generally exhibits the best performance across different difficulty levels and test categories when compared to other models, although there is still potential for advancement, particularly in handling highly complex tasks.

The MMMU benchmark presents a notable challenge for even advanced models, as highlighted by GPT-4V's accuracy of only $55.7\%$ [1, 4].  Analyzing performance across different difficulty levels reveals that GPT-4V exhibits a significantly higher success rate in the "Easy" category, achieving $76.1\%$ compared to open-source models [6].

![Performance comparison across Easy, Medium, Hard, and Overall difficulty levels for various models, including LLaVA-1.5-13B and GPT-4V.](image1)

While this performance gap narrows in the "Medium" category, GPT-4V still leads with $55.6\%$ [7].  Interestingly, in the "Hard" category, the performance difference between GPT-4V and open-source models becomes less pronounced, suggesting that even advanced models struggle with expert-level complex queries [7]. This trend is evident when comparing the performance of LLaVA-1.5-13B and GPT-4V across these levels, as shown in a detailed breakdown of model performances across varying difficulty levels [image1].

Furthermore, the benchmark reveals variations in model performance across different disciplines.  Models generally perform better in areas like Art & Design and Humanities & Social Sciences, where visual data is often less complex [3, 12].

![Performance comparison across various disciplines for different Large Multimodal Models (LMMs), including LLaVA-1.5-13B and GPT-4V.](image3)

Conversely, disciplines such as Business, Science, Health & Medicine, and Tech & Engineering, which involve more intricate visual data and demand complex reasoning, see comparatively lower model performance [3, 12].
