In 2019, Cloud & Cognitive Software demonstrated a notably higher external gross profit of $17,650 million and a pre-tax income of $7,811 million, contrasting with Global Business Services (GBS), which reported an external gross profit of $4,655 million and a pre-tax income of $1,623 million ![Cloud & Cognitive Software had an external gross profit of $17,650 million and a pre-tax income of $7,811 million in 2019](image4)![Global Business Services had an external gross profit of $4,655 million and a pre-tax income of $1,623 million in 2019](image6). The financial results for Cloud & Cognitive Software were notably impacted by the acquisition of Red Hat, which led to purchase price accounting effects that contributed to a gross profit margin decline. Furthermore, investments in key strategic areas and a reduction in income from IP partnership agreements also contributed to a decrease in pre-tax income for this segment [7]. Conversely, the year-over-year improvements in margins and pre-tax income within GBS were primarily driven by a strategic shift towards higher-value offerings, enhanced delivery productivity, and favorable currency effects resulting from the global delivery resource model [3].

Cloud & Cognitive Software significantly outperformed Global Business Services in terms of both external gross profit and pre-tax income in 2019, with varied factors shaping these financial outcomes for each segment.

In Latin America & Canada, there was a notable decrease in total shipment volume, declining by $11.6\%$ in 2020 compared to 2019 [2].  This decrease in shipment volume is further detailed regionally, with Latin America & Canada experiencing a $10.3\%$ drop, excluding the impact of RBH deconsolidation [10]. This regional decline was primarily driven by lower cigarette shipment volumes, most significantly in Argentina and Mexico, although partially offset by an increase in Brazil [10].  Argentina faced a $12.2\%$ decrease due to reduced market share and stock issues, while Mexico saw an $18.0\%$ decrease due to a lower market and reduced market share attributed to smokers switching to cheaper brands and pandemic-related consumption changes [12]. Conversely, Brazil experienced a $13.4\%$ increase, largely attributed to a reduction in illicit trade because of smaller price differences with legal products and border restrictions during the pandemic [5].

Despite the challenges in shipment volumes, the financial performance in Latin America & Canada presents a mixed picture.  The region experienced a decrease in net revenues by $22.9\%$ from 2019 to 2020, but remarkably, operating income increased by over 100% during the same period ![Financial performance in Latin America and Canada from 2019 to 2020, showing a decrease in Net Revenues and an increase in Operating Income](image5). This suggests that while revenue generation faced headwinds, profitability was significantly enhanced, potentially through cost management or other operational efficiencies.  Overall, while shipment volumes and net revenues decreased in Latin America & Canada, operating income saw a substantial increase from 2019 to 2020.

The net income for Consumer Banking and Lending experienced a significant fluctuation over the period. From a robust \$5,895 million in 2019, it sharply declined to \$1,076 million in 2020, before rebounding dramatically to \$8,555 million in 2021 [image4]. This indicates a considerable recovery and growth in profitability for this segment by 2021.

![Net income for Consumer Banking and Lending fluctuated significantly between 2019 and 2021.](image4)

Regarding the balance sheet, total loans for Consumer Banking and Lending showed a decreasing trend.  As indicated in the data, "Total loans (average and period-end) decreased as paydowns exceeded originations" [5].  This is reflected in the average total loans which were \$379,766 million in 2019, \$376,463 million in 2020, and further decreased to \$333,885 million in 2021 [image2].  Specifically within loan categories, Home Lending loans saw a consistent decrease, influenced by strategic decisions in 2020 to limit certain mortgage originations [5].

![Total loans for Consumer Banking and Lending decreased from 2019 to 2021, while total deposits increased.](image2)

Conversely, total deposits demonstrated a strong upward trend throughout this period.  "Total deposits (average and period-end) increased driven by higher levels of liquidity and savings for consumer customers reflecting government stimulus programs and payment deferral programs, as well as continued economic uncertainty associated with the COVID-19 pandemic" [11]. Average total deposits increased from \$629,110 million in 2019 to \$722,085 million in 2020, and further to \$834,739 million in 2021 [image2]. This growth in deposits suggests an influx of funds, potentially due to external economic factors and changing consumer behaviors during the examined years.

In summary, from 2019 to 2021, Consumer Banking and Lending experienced a fluctuating net income with a strong recovery in 2021, a decrease in total loans, particularly in home lending, and a substantial increase in total deposits.

Between 2019 and 2021, there were notable shifts in key financial metrics.  Average Card Member loans saw a decrease from $69.4 billion to $61.0 billion, as shown in the financial data ![Financial data comparison over years](image7). This is further corroborated by text quote [12] which indicates lower average revolving Card Member loan balances.

However, despite the decrease in average loan balances, the net interest income also experienced a reduction, moving from $7,683 million in 2019 to $6,674 million in 2021 ![Financial data comparison over years](image7).  This decrease in net interest income is explained in quote [2] as being "primarily due to a decrease in net interest yields driven by higher paydown rates on revolving loan balances."  Quote [10] also mentions that "Card Member loans increased 21 percent, which was lower than the growth in billed business due to higher paydown rates".

Despite the decrease in net interest income, the company demonstrated overall revenue growth and strong financial health [8]. Total revenues net of interest expense actually increased by 17 percent year-over-year [2], and non-interest revenues also saw significant growth [6], as confirmed in the revenue breakdown ![Revenue changes over years](image2).  This growth in non-interest revenue, along with effective management of provisions for credit losses [4], contributed to a strong overall financial performance, even with the reduced net interest income.

In conclusion, while average Card Member loans and net interest income decreased from 2019 to 2021, the company's financial performance remained strong due to growth in other revenue streams and effective financial management.

The company classifies its Research and Development (R&D) expenditures into three primary categories [10]. These are research and early pipeline, which covers early research phases; later-stage clinical programs, focusing on phase 2 and 3 clinical trials; and marketed products, which supports products already on the market  ![These categories include early research, phase 2 and 3 clinical trials, and marketed product support](image5). In 2020, the breakdown of expenses across these categories reveals that research and early pipeline amounted to \$1,405 million, later-stage clinical programs accounted for \$1,365 million, and marketed products totaled \$1,437 million, culminating in a total R&D expense of \$4,207 million ![Breakdown of R&D expenses by category for 2018-2020](image1).  In summary, the main R&D expense categories are research and early pipeline, later-stage clinical programs, and marketed products.

Accenture's financial statements, prepared under U.S. generally accepted accounting principles, involve management's careful estimations [1]. Share-based compensation, a non-cash expense, significantly influences shareholders' equity by increasing additional paid-in capital, as seen in the Consolidated Shareholders’ Equity Statements ![Share-based compensation increases additional paid-in capital in shareholder's equity statement](image2). Siemens Healthineers experienced a notable shift in its financial structure between 2020 and 2021.  Equity saw a significant rise, increasing by €3,828 million to reach €16,339 million [7]. This growth was primarily fueled by the issuance of new shares in March 2021, specifically to finance the acquisition of Varian [7]. This is further detailed in the components of equity, where the capital reserve increased substantially to €15,818 million in 2021 from €13,476 million in 2020, alongside a rise in issued capital to €1,128 million from €1,075 million ![Total equity attributable to shareholders of Siemens Healthineers AG increased significantly from 12,498 in 2020 to 16,321 in 2021, with capital reserve and issued capital as major components](image6).  Conversely, retained earnings decreased, partially offsetting the equity increase.

However, this equity surge was accompanied by a considerable increase in liabilities.  Net debt, including pensions, dramatically rose from €2,513 million in 2020 to €12,809 million in 2021 ![Net debt (including pensions) increased significantly from 2,513 in 2020 to 12,809 in 2021](image3). This surge in debt is largely attributed to borrowings undertaken to finance the Varian acquisition [12].  Specifically, Siemens Group provided substantial financing, including borrowings of €10 billion and an additional €850 million [12].  The rise in liabilities is also reflected in the increased liabilities to the Siemens Group from financing activities, which jumped from €2,982 million to €11,708 million ![Liabilities to the Siemens Group from financing activities increased significantly from 2,982 in 2020 to 11,708 in 2021](image1).  Despite the capital increase boosting equity, the equity ratio declined from 76% to 55%, highlighting the more pronounced increase in loan liabilities [4].

In summary, Siemens Healthineers' equity increased substantially due to new share issuance for the Varian acquisition, while liabilities also dramatically increased due to borrowings for the same acquisition, leading to a reduced equity ratio despite the equity growth.

In 2021, financing activities were notably influenced by both the issuance and redemption of preferred shares [1].  The company issued $1.6 billion of new preferred shares, while simultaneously redeeming older series of preferred shares totaling $1.6 billion [10].  This activity is clearly reflected in the cash flow statement, where we see positive cash flow from the issuance and negative cash flow from the redemption of preferred shares in 2021. ![Cash flow statement showing issuance and redemption of preferred shares in 2021](image3).  Looking at the changes in shareholders' equity, the issuance increased preferred shares, while the redemption reduced it, resulting in a net change in the preferred shares balance.  ![Shareholder equity changes, reflecting preferred share transactions](image7).  Although the cash flow statement in image3 shows these activities only for 2021, the shareholder equity statement in image7 shows the balances of preferred shares for both 2020 and 2021, and image4 also shows the preferred shares in shareholders' equity. ![Shareholders' equity including preferred shares](image4).  In summary, the issuance and redemption of preferred shares in 2021 led to a complex but ultimately cash neutral transaction in financing activities and adjustments within shareholders' equity, specifically in preferred share capital.

The consolidated segment experienced an increase in total assets and operating cash flow between 2020 and 2021.  Total assets for the consolidated segment rose to $82,793 million in 2021 from $78,324 million in 2020, indicating a significant increase in the company's resources ![Total assets for the consolidated segment increased from $78,324 million in 2020 to $82,793 million in 2021](image1).  Similarly, net cash provided by operating activities saw a substantial rise, reaching $7.198 billion in 2021 compared to $6.327 billion in 2020 [5]. This improvement was largely due to higher profits in 2021, adjusted for non-cash items, and the favorable impact of lower short-term incentive compensation payments [1, 5]. The detailed breakdown of operating cash flow components in the supplemental data further illustrates this positive change, comparing figures from 2021 and 2020 ![Operating cash flow components for the consolidated segment in 2021 and 2020](image2).  While there were increased working capital requirements that partially offset these gains, the overall trend in operating cash flow remained strongly positive [1, 5].  This growth in both assets and operating cash flow implies improved financial health and operational efficiency for the consolidated business, potentially enabling further investments and strategic initiatives.  The consolidated segment demonstrated positive changes in both total assets and operating cash flow from 2020 to 2021, suggesting a stronger financial footing and enhanced operational capabilities.

Total assets experienced a slight decrease from $191,367 million in 2020 to $188,548 million in 2021, while total liabilities also saw a reduction, moving from $168,383 million to $166,371 million ![Total assets and liabilities in 2020 and 2021 are shown in the balance sheet.](image1). This overall contraction in the balance sheet occurred despite a significant rise in net income, which jumped from $3,135 million in 2020 to $8,060 million in 2021 ![Net income significantly increased from 2020 to 2021, while other comprehensive income decreased.](image2).  The company highlights in [9] that the decrease in cash and cash equivalents, contributing to the asset reduction, was primarily due to increased Card Member loans and receivables, debt maturities, and share repurchases.  Despite the reduced balance sheet size, the company's cash flow from operating activities substantially improved to $14,645 million in 2021 from $5,591 million in the prior year, as shown in the cash flow statement ![Cash flow from operating activities increased significantly from 2020 to 2021.](image7), reflecting enhanced operational efficiency and profitability. In summary, while the company's total assets and liabilities slightly decreased, its comprehensive income and operating cash flow saw substantial improvements, indicating a stronger financial performance in 2021 compared to 2020.

In 2020, Wealth and Personal Banking (WPB) reported a net operating income of $22,013 million, as part of its adjusted revenue [image7]. Commercial Banking (CMB), represented by segments like Global Trade and Receivables Finance, Credit and Lending, and Global Liquidity and Cash Management, recorded a combined net operating income of $13,312 million [image5].  These figures indicate that WPB achieved a higher net operating income compared to CMB in 2020. In the European Union, there was a decrease in cigarette shipment volume, as indicated by "lower cigarette shipment volume, notably in Italy and Poland" [7]. This is further evidenced by data showing a decrease from 174,319 million units in 2019 to 163,420 million units in 2020, a 6.3% reduction ![Cigarette shipment volume decreased in EU from 2019 to 2020](image2).  Conversely, the shipment volume of heated tobacco units in the European Union experienced a significant increase. Textual evidence points to "higher heated tobacco unit shipment volume across the Region (notably in Germany, Italy and Poland)" [8].  Data confirms this trend, revealing an increase in heated tobacco unit shipments from 12,569 million units in 2019 to 19,842 million units in 2020, marking a substantial 57.9% rise ![Heated tobacco unit shipment volume increased significantly in EU from 2019 to 2020](image2).

Turning to Eastern Europe, while cigarette shipment volumes also decreased, as suggested by "partly offset by lower cigarette shipment volume, mainly in Russia and Ukraine" [11], the region saw an overall slight increase in total shipment volume.  Specifically, cigarette shipment volume decreased from 100,644 million units in 2019 to 93,462 million units in 2020, a 7.1% decrease ![Cigarette shipment volume decreased in Eastern Europe from 2019 to 2020](image8).  Mirroring the EU, Eastern Europe witnessed a significant surge in heated tobacco unit shipment volumes, supported by the text stating "higher heated tobacco unit shipment volume across the Region, notably in Russia and Ukraine" [11]. Data substantiates this, showing a considerable increase from 13,453 million units in 2019 to 20,898 million units in 2020, a 55.3% increase ![Heated tobacco unit shipment volume increased significantly in Eastern Europe from 2019 to 2020](image8).

In summary, both the European Union and Eastern Europe experienced a decrease in cigarette shipment volumes and a significant increase in heated tobacco unit shipment volumes between 2019 and 2020.

Tata Consultancy Services has shown a strong commitment to the Japanese market by increasing its stake in Tata Consultancy Services Japan, Ltd., a joint venture with Mitsubishi Corporation. Initially holding $51\%$, TCS incrementally raised its equity to $66\%$ [5, 11]. This strategic move is part of a broader investment strategy to better serve the specific needs of Japanese corporations.

![Tata Consultancy Services Japan, Ltd. has 66% shares held and applicable section 2(87)](image5)

In contrast, for Tata Consultancy Services Italia s.r.l. located in Italy, the shareholding percentage is $100\%$.

![Tata Consultancy Services Italia s.r.l. has 100% shares held and applicable section 2(87)](image8)

Both Tata Consultancy Services Japan, Ltd. and TCS Italia s.r.l. fall under the same applicable section, 2(87). The percentage of shares held in Tata Consultancy Services Japan, Ltd. is $66\%$ and in TCS Italia s.r.l. is $100\%$, both under applicable section 2(87).

From 2019 to 2020, there's a notable shift in IBM's financial figures.  Total equity experienced a decrease of $258 million, primarily due to dividend payouts and a decline in accumulated other comprehensive income, although this was partially offset by net income and common stock increases [1]. In the Global Financing segment, total assets saw a decrease from $29,568 million to $25,075 million between 2019 and 2020, as part of the shifts in financial position within this segment ![Total assets in Global Financing segment decreased in 2020 compared to 2019](image6).  Simultaneously, total company debt saw a reduction, moving from $62,899 million in 2019 to $61,538 million in 2020, indicating a positive step in debt management ![Total company debt decreased from 2019 to 2020](image1). The company's debt reduction is also highlighted by an overall decrease of $1,361 million from the previous year-end [9].

In summary, IBM's financial position in 2020 showed a decrease in total equity and total company debt compared to 2019.

Operating lease liabilities are detailed in the lease assets and liabilities classification, showing a total of \$974 million in 2020 compared to \$719 million in 2019, indicating an increase in these liabilities year-over-year. ![Operating lease liabilities increased in 2020 compared to 2019](image2).  Looking at inventories, the breakdown of finished goods, work in process, and raw materials sums to a total inventory value of \$2,292 million in 2020 and \$1,628 million in 2019, reflecting a notable increase in inventory holdings in the more recent year. ![Inventory holdings were higher in 2020 than in 2019](image5). In summary, both operating lease liabilities and inventory totals were higher in 2020 compared to 2019.

Tata Consultancy Services' shareholding structure remained largely stable between April 1, 2019, and March 31, 2020.  The promoter group, primarily Tata Sons Private Limited, maintained a consistent shareholding.  Tata Sons Private Limited held 2,702,450,947 shares, representing $72.0\%$ of the company's total shares at both the beginning and end of the fiscal year [6].  This significant portion underscores the Tata group's controlling stake in TCS.  ![Tata group's consistent shareholding](image6)

Similarly, other entities within the Tata group, such as Tata Industries Limited, Tata Investment Corporation Limited, Tata Steel Limited, and The Tata Power Company Limited, showed no change in their shareholdings during this period [8].  ![Breakdown of Tata group shareholding](image4) This indicates a strategic long-term investment approach from these entities.  Looking at public shareholding, while the total percentage remained constant at $28.0\%$ [image2], there were minor shifts within different categories of public shareholders.  For instance, Mutual Funds/UTI and Insurance Companies slightly increased their holdings, while Individual shareholders holding nominal share capital in excess of ₹1 lakh saw a decrease [image8]. These shifts suggest portfolio adjustments by various investor types within the public domain, without altering the overall public shareholding proportion.

In conclusion, the shareholding pattern of TCS experienced minimal change between April 1, 2019, and March 31, 2020, with both promoter and public categories maintaining largely consistent ownership percentages, although there were minor internal reallocations within public shareholder categories.

From 2018 to 2020, there was a notable increase in the company's gross unrecognized tax benefits, escalating from $1,056 million in 2018 to $1,829 million in 2020, with an intermediate value of $1,423 million in 2019, reflecting a consistent upward trend over these years ![Gross unrecognized tax benefits increased from 2018 to 2020.](image4). The company implements a share repurchase program with the aim of refining its capital structure and lowering capital costs, ultimately boosting shareholder returns and neutralizing the dilutive effects of share-based awards [3].  In terms of common share repurchases, the number of shares repurchased decreased from 22 million in 2019 to 14 million in 2020, while the average price per share increased from $245.97 to $300.58, resulting in a decrease in aggregate cost from $5,500 million to $4,250 million over the same period ![Common share repurchases decreased in shares but increased in average price per share from 2019 to 2020.](image8) [8].

The company's gross unrecognized tax benefits increased from $1,056 million in 2018 to $1,829 million in 2020, and common share repurchases led to a strategic adjustment in capital without a consistent increase in aggregate cost between 2019 and 2020.

Initially, the adoption of AASB 16 had a significant impact, leading to the recognition of right-of-use assets [1, 2, 5, 12].  This is evident in the right-of-use assets' balance at the start of fiscal year 2020, which was $138,403,000 ![Schedule of right-of-use asset cost at the beginning of fiscal year 2020](image6). Throughout the year, this amount rose to $150,464,000 by June 28, 2020 ![Schedule of right-of-use asset cost at the end of fiscal year 2020](image6). This increase was influenced by factors such as additions, re-measurements of lease liabilities, and foreign exchange fluctuations, while being partially offset by depreciation and impairment charges [6, 7].  In parallel, the carrying amount of leasehold improvements, hardware, and software also experienced growth. At the beginning of the fiscal year, it was $38,418,000 ![Carrying amount of leasehold improvements, hardware and software at the beginning of fiscal year 2020](image1), and by year-end, it reached $46,099,000 ![Carrying amount of leasehold improvements, hardware and software at the end of fiscal year 2020](image1). This change was attributed to additions, offset by depreciation, disposals and exchange rate fluctuations as shown in the depreciation schedule. The carrying amounts of leasehold improvements, hardware and software, and right-of-use assets all increased during fiscal year 2020, driven by additions and the initial adoption of AASB 16 for right-of-use assets, with depreciation partially mitigating these increases.

Qualcomm's tax landscape has seen notable shifts across the fiscal years 2019 to 2021.  In 2019, a significant tax benefit of \$570 million arose from "check-the-box" elections related to foreign subsidiaries, establishing new U.S. deferred tax assets [8]. However, this year also saw a \$2.5 billion charge to income tax expense due to changes in regulations regarding the deductibility of dividend income, effectively negating a previously recognized deferred tax asset [8].  The effective tax rate in 2019 was notably high at 41%, influenced by these factors along with the derecognition of deferred tax assets on distributed intellectual property and other adjustments ![The effective tax rate was 41% in 2019 due to several factors](image7). This contrasts sharply with the lower effective tax rates of 9% in 2020 and 12% in 2021 ![The effective tax rates decreased to 9% and 12% in 2020 and 2021 respectively](image7).

Moving into 2020, the global impact of COVID-19 led to investment impairments, affecting the tax situation indirectly [7].  Despite these challenges, the total tax benefits related to share-based awards continued to grow, reaching \$273 million in 2020, up from \$237 million in 2019, and further increasing to \$567 million in 2021 [1]. This upward trend in share-based award tax benefits reflects a consistent increase over these years ![Tax benefits from share-based awards have consistently increased from 2019 to 2021](image4).  Furthermore, unrecognized tax benefits have also seen an increase, rising from \$1.9 billion in 2020 to \$2.1 billion in 2021, largely attributed to expected refunds of Korean withholding taxes [10, image8].

The geographic distribution of income tax provisions also shows trends, with the United States consistently accounting for the majority of the provision across all three years ![The US consistently accounts for the majority of the income tax provision](image5).  Overall, while specific events like the 2019 tax regulation changes caused significant fluctuations, there's a general trend of increasing tax benefits from share-based awards and a rising level of unrecognized tax benefits primarily linked to international tax matters. The income tax provision amount was \$3,095 million in 2019, \$521 million in 2020 and \$1,231 million in 2021, showing considerable volatility over the period ![Income tax provision amounts fluctuated between 2019 and 2021](image9).

In summary, Qualcomm's tax provisions and benefits experienced significant changes and trends between 2019 and 2021, marked by regulatory impacts in 2019, COVID-related influences in 2020, and increasing unrecognized tax benefits in 2021, alongside a consistent rise in share-based compensation tax benefits.

The sale of Wells Fargo Asset Management (WFAM) on November 1, 2021, significantly altered the company's assets under management and financial statements.  Prior to the sale, WFAM managed a substantial portfolio, offering Wells Fargo proprietary mutual funds and managed institutional separate accounts, generating fees based on the market value of these assets [5, 7].  As depicted in the WFAM Assets Under Management table, the sale on November 1, 2021, resulted in a significant outflow of assets, specifically $\S587.1$ billion, effectively removing WFAM's AUM from Wells Fargo's balance sheet ![The sale of WFAM in 2021 led to a substantial decrease in assets under management.](image2).

This divestiture directly boosted Wells Fargo's income statement.  The company recorded a net gain of $\S269$ million from the WFAM sale [1], contributing to an increase in other income for the year 2021 [2].  The Income Statement overview shows a substantial rise in Noninterest income from $\S4,916$ million in 2020 to $\S10,036$ million in 2021, reflecting such gains from business sales ![Noninterest income significantly increased in 2021 compared to 2020.](image1). However, the sale of WFAM also led to lower asset-based fees in noninterest income in the periods following the sale [4].  Moreover, examining the Income Statement for the Wealth and Investment Management division, we see that Investment advisory and other asset-based fees increased in 2021, but this is a general trend and the sale would eventually lead to a decrease in these fees in subsequent periods due to the absence of WFAM ![Investment advisory fees increased year over year, but the WFAM sale implies potential future decreases.](image3).

While the sale provided a one-time gain, it also influenced the balance sheet. Total assets modestly decreased, partially offset by an increase in equity securities [8]. The removal of WFAM's assets contributed to this overall asset reduction.  The balance sheet data shows slight decreases in total assets year-over-year, which can be in part attributed to strategic divestitures like the WFAM sale ![Total assets saw a minor decrease from 2020 to 2021.](image7).

In conclusion, the sale of WFAM in 2021 markedly reduced Wells Fargo's assets under management, generated a significant one-time gain boosting noninterest income, and contributed to adjustments in the company's overall balance sheet.

In Wealth and Personal Banking (WPB), the reported revenue experienced an increase from \$24,232m in 2018 to \$25,552m in 2019, as shown in the financial data breakdown ![WPB reported revenue increased in 2019](image6) compared to ![WPB reported revenue in 2018](image8). In contrast, the reported operating expenses for WPB also rose from \$15,522m in 2018 to \$17,351m in 2019, according to the detailed financial statements ![WPB reported operating expenses increased in 2019](image6) and ![WPB reported operating expenses in 2018](image8).  In Wealth and Personal Banking, both reported revenue and operating expenses were higher in 2019 than in 2018.

In 2020, net interest income experienced a decrease to $43.4 billion from $48.9 billion in 2019 [6, Image5]. This decline was largely attributed to lower interest rates, although this was partially mitigated by reduced deposit and funding costs, strategic deployment of excess deposits into securities, and an extra day of interest accrual [6].  The net interest yield also decreased by 53 basis points, reaching 1.90 percent in 2020 [6].  The net interest spread, which reflects the difference between interest income and interest expense relative to earning assets, narrowed from 2.34% in 2019 to 1.94% in 2020  ![Net interest spread decreased from 2019 to 2020](image3).

Examining the components of interest income and expense reveals the impact of rate and volume changes across different asset and liability categories.  For instance, interest income from debt securities decreased by $4,237 million due to changes in rate, while increasing by $2,188 million due to volume changes from 2019 to 2020 ![Changes in interest income for debt securities](image1).  Similarly, interest expense on demand and money market deposit accounts decreased significantly by $4,001 million due to rate changes and increased by $507 million due to volume changes ![Changes in interest expense for demand and money market deposit accounts](image1).  These shifts highlight that while lower interest rates reduced both income and expense, the net effect was a decrease in net interest income, leading to a narrower net interest spread.

In summary, the net interest spread decreased from 2019 to 2020, primarily due to a greater reduction in net interest income than in net interest expense, predominantly driven by the impact of lower interest rates, despite some offsetting effects from volume changes and cost management.

In 2020, to reconcile IFRS operating loss to core operating loss for Sandoz, there were positive adjustments from other income and negative adjustments from other expenses, with other income contributing 644 million USD and other expenses reducing by 488 million USD.  ![In 2020, adjustments to operating loss included positive other income and negative other expense.](image5)  However, in 2021, while other income still provided a positive adjustment of 470 million USD, other expenses increased to 618 million USD, indicating a larger negative impact on the operating loss compared to the previous year. ![In 2021, adjustments to operating loss also included positive other income and negative other expense, but with different magnitudes compared to 2020.](image6)  The key difference lies in the shift from a net positive adjustment in 2020 to a net negative adjustment in 2021, primarily driven by a larger other expense in 2021.

The adjustments to arrive at core operating income for Sandoz show a shift from a net positive adjustment in 2020 to a net negative adjustment in 2021, mainly due to increased other expenses in 2021.

In both 2020 and 2021, the adjustments for amortization of intangible assets increased the core operating income for the group.  In 2021, the amortization of intangible assets adjustment was USD 3,764 million, contributing to an increase from the IFRS operating income of USD 11,689 million to a core operating income of USD 16,588 million for continuing operations ![Table showing 2021 adjustments including 3,764 million for Amortization of intangible assets, leading to a core operating income of 16,588 million](image8). Similarly in 2020, the amortization of intangible assets adjustment was USD 3,365 million, increasing the IFRS operating income from continuing operations of USD 10,152 million to a core operating income of USD 15,416 million ![Table showing 2020 adjustments including 3,365 million for Amortization of intangible assets, leading to a core operating income of 15,416 million](image4). Amortization of intangible assets positively adjusted the operating income to reach core operating income in both years.

In 2021, the corporation witnessed a significant increase in consolidated operating profit compared to 2020, as depicted in the visual representation of operating profit changes across different factors ![This chart shows the breakdown of changes in consolidated operating profit between Q4 2020 and Q4 2021, highlighting the impact of sales volume, price realization, manufacturing costs, SG&A/R&D, currency, financial products, and other factors.](image2). Between 2019 and 2020, the company's gross unrecognized tax benefits saw a significant increase, rising from $1,423 million to $1,829 million, as depicted in the summary of changes in unrecognized tax benefits across the years ![Gross unrecognized tax benefits increased from 2019 to 2020.](image5).  This increase is further detailed within the statement, showing the beginning and ending balances for gross unrecognized tax benefits over three years [5].  Despite this rise in unrecognized tax benefits, the company anticipates a potential decrease of $39 million in the next twelve months due to audit settlements and statute of limitations expiring [6]. It's also noted that if these unrecognized tax benefits were to be recognized, they would have a direct impact on the company's effective tax rate [12].

Conversely, common share repurchases experienced a decrease in aggregate cost, falling from $5,500 million in 2019 to $4,250 million in 2020, although the number of shares repurchased decreased less dramatically from 22 million to 14 million as illustrated in the summary of share repurchases ![Common share repurchases decreased in aggregate cost but also in number of shares between 2019 and 2020.](image1).  This shift in share repurchase activity occurred within the context of the company's ongoing share repurchase program, which is authorized by the Board of Directors and periodically evaluated [7, 11]. While the aggregate cost of repurchases decreased, the average price per share increased from $245.97 to $300.58 [image1], reflecting market conditions and strategic decisions in executing the repurchase program.

In conclusion, the company experienced an increase in gross unrecognized tax benefits alongside a decrease in the aggregate cost of common share repurchases between 2019 and 2020, indicating shifts in potential tax liabilities and capital allocation strategies.

The fourth quarter of 2021 witnessed a substantial surge in sales and revenues, reaching $\Updownarrow\uparrow\,\!3.798$ billion, marking a 23 percent increase compared to $\S\uparrow\uparrow.235$ billion in the same quarter of 2020 [3]. This growth was largely propelled by an upswing in sales volume, fueled by heightened end-user demand for both equipment and services. Changes in dealer inventories also played a significant role, with dealers decreasing inventories less in Q4 2021 compared to a more substantial decrease in Q4 2020 [3]. Dealers' inventory adjustments reflect their anticipation of future demand and product delivery schedules, influenced by seasonal trends, economic conditions, and machine rental rates [8].

![Sales volume significantly contributed to the increase in sales and revenues.](image8)

Examining the consolidated operating profit, we see an increase to $\S1.611$ billion in the fourth quarter of 2021, a 17 percent rise from $\Updownarrow\uparrow.380$ billion in the fourth quarter of 2020 [12]. While higher sales volume and favorable price realization were key drivers for this profit growth, increased manufacturing costs, along with SG&A and R&D expenses, partially moderated the overall increase [12].  The contribution of sales volume and offsetting manufacturing costs can be visually understood in the context of operating profit.

![Sales volume increased operating profit, but manufacturing costs partially offset the gain.](image4)

In summary, both sales volume and operating profit experienced significant growth in the fourth quarter of 2021 compared to the same period in 2020. This was primarily driven by increased end-user demand and changes in dealer inventories, although rising manufacturing costs and operating expenses partially offset the operating profit gains.

Consumer Banking experienced a decrease in net interest income and total revenue in 2020 compared to 2019 [5].  Net interest income for Consumer Banking was $24,698 million in 2020, a decrease from $28,158 million in 2019, representing a 12% drop. Total revenue, net of interest expense, for Consumer Banking also declined to $33,262 million in 2020 from $38,587 million in 2019, a decrease of 14%, as detailed in the financial performance summary. ![Financial performance of Consumer Banking and Consumer Lending in 2020 vs 2019](image1).

Similarly, the Wealth Management sector, specifically Merrill Lynch Global Wealth Management (MLGWM), also saw a decrease in both net interest income and total revenue. MLGWM's revenue decreased by five percent, primarily due to lower interest rates, although this was partially offset by higher market valuations and positive Asset Under Management (AUM) flows [6]. In both 2020 and 2021, there were notable differences between IFRS and core results for net income and basic EPS. In 2020, under IFRS, the net income was USD 8,071 million and the basic EPS was USD 3.55, while core results showed a higher net income of USD 13,158 million and a basic EPS of USD 5.78, as detailed in the provided financial data ![Comparison of IFRS and Core Results for 2020](image6).  Conversely, in 2021, this trend reversed. The IFRS net income was significantly higher at USD 24,018 million with a basic EPS of USD 10.71, but the core results indicated a lower net income of USD 14,094 million and a basic EPS of USD 6.29, as illustrated in the financial breakdown ![Comparison of IFRS and Core Results for 2021](image8).

The shift in net income and EPS from 2020 to 2021 is largely attributable to varying adjustments. In 2020, a significant positive adjustment stemmed from the 'Amortization of intangible assets,' which contributed to the increase in core income relative to IFRS income ![Adjustments for 2020](image6). However, in 2021, the most impactful adjustment was 'Acquisition or divestment of businesses and related items,' which presented a substantial negative value. This suggests that in 2021, a considerable divestment gain was recognized under IFRS, inflating the IFRS net income, whereas such gains are typically excluded from core results, leading to a lower core net income compared to the IFRS figure ![Adjustments for 2021](image8).

In summary, core net income and basic EPS were higher than IFRS in 2020, primarily due to positive adjustments like amortization, but in 2021, core figures became lower than IFRS because of a significant negative adjustment related to business divestments.

In 2021, Chevron's equity structure and cash flow were significantly influenced by both cash dividends and treasury stock transactions.  Cash dividends, as seen in the consolidated statement of equity, amounted to $10,179 [Image5]. This distribution to stockholders directly reduced retained earnings, a component of stockholders' equity, as reflected in the decrease in retained earnings from $160,377 in 2020 to $165,546 in 2021, despite a net income of $15,625 [Image5, Image8].  Cash dividends are also clearly presented as a cash outflow in the cash flow statement under financing activities, totaling $(10,179) for common stock [Image6], directly decreasing the company's cash balance.

Treasury stock transactions also played a role.  While there were issuances and purchases of treasury shares [Image5], the net effect, as shown in the cash flow statement, was a net sale of treasury shares amounting to $38 [Image6]. This indicates that Chevron issued slightly more treasury shares than it repurchased in 2021, resulting in a minor increase in cash from financing activities.  However, looking at the consolidated statement of equity, the treasury stock at cost decreased slightly from $(41,498) in 2020 to $(41,464) in 2021 [Image5], suggesting a minor reduction in the contra-equity account.  The balance sheet also reflects these values for treasury stock [Image8].

![Cash dividends reduced retained earnings and treasury stock transactions had a minor net positive cash flow impact.](image6)

In summary, cash dividends significantly decreased both Chevron's retained earnings and cash flow, while treasury stock transactions had a negligible net impact, slightly increasing cash flow and marginally decreasing the treasury stock contra-equity account in 2021.

Building on this achievement, HSBC has set a new target to increase female representation in senior leadership to $35\%$ by 2025 [3, 10]. ![In 2020, among all HSBC employees, the gender distribution was fairly balanced with 52% female and 48% male, while senior leadership was composed of 70% male and 30% female.](image4)

As shown in the image, while the overall employee base exhibits a near equal gender split, senior leadership still skews towards male representation. This indicates a disparity in gender representation as one ascends the organizational hierarchy.

The adoption of AASB 16 *Leases* from 1 July 2019 marked a significant shift in lease accounting [6]. This new standard moved away from the previous classification of leases as either operating or finance leases for lessees, introducing a unified on-balance sheet model [4].  Consequently, the Group, acting as a lessee, recognized right-of-use assets, representing the right to use leased assets, and lease liabilities, reflecting the obligation to make lease payments [4].  Upon transitioning to AASB 16, lease liabilities, which were previously classified as operating leases under AASB 117, were initially measured at the present value of the remaining lease payments. This calculation was discounted using the Group’s incremental borrowing rate as of 1 July 2019 [9].

![Lease liabilities significantly increased due to adopting AASB 16 and other factors in 2020.](image1)

The consolidated financial statement shows the impact of this transition, with a substantial recognition of lease liabilities upon the initial application of AASB 16, reaching $43,620,000 [image1]. Throughout the period, lease liabilities were further affected by new leases, re-measurements, lease payments, and interest, culminating in a total balance of $67,154,000 by 28 June 2020 [image1, 7].  Notably, under AASB 16, the Group ceased to recognize separate provisions for onerous leases. Instead, obligations from these leases are now incorporated within the lease liability itself [2].

![AASB 16 integrates onerous lease obligations into lease liabilities, removing the need for separate provisions.](image2)

Furthermore, the accounting for site restoration costs and straight-lining of prepaid rent was also altered. Site restoration costs are now capitalized as part of the right-of-use asset and depreciated over the lease term, a change from prior periods where restoration provisions were linked to leasehold improvements [3]. Similarly, the straight-lining prepaid rent account was capitalized into the right-of-use asset, eliminating the recognition of separate provisions for straight-line rent and lease incentives [7].

![AASB 16 shifted the accounting for straight-lining prepaid rent and lease incentives into right-of-use assets and lease liabilities.](image7)

In contrast, the impact on employee benefit liabilities appears to be less dramatic. These liabilities, encompassing annual leave and long-service leave, are calculated based on expected future wage rates and discounted to present value [1, 10]. The consolidated figures for employee benefit liabilities show a relatively stable position, with a slight increase from $4,054,000 in 2019 to $4,092,000 in 2020 [image3].

![Employee benefit liabilities remained relatively stable between 2019 and 2020.](image3)

In 2020, the transition to AASB 16 significantly increased lease liabilities while employee benefit liabilities remained relatively consistent with the previous year.

Both the ClickSoftware and Salesforce.org acquisitions involved allocating the fair value of net assets acquired, with goodwill being a significant component in both cases. For ClickSoftware, a substantial \$1.132 billion was recorded as goodwill, primarily attributed to the assembled workforce and expanded market opportunities [8].  ![Goodwill was a major component in ClickSoftware's fair value allocation](image8). Similarly, the Salesforce.org acquisition also resulted in goodwill, although a smaller amount of \$164 million, with the same attribution to assembled workforce and market expansion [6]. ![Goodwill was also present in Salesforce.org's fair value allocation, though smaller](image1).

A key difference lies in the scale of the acquisitions. ClickSoftware's net assets acquired amounted to \$1.386 billion ![Net assets acquired for ClickSoftware were significant](image8), reflecting a much larger acquisition compared to Salesforce.org, where net assets acquired were only \$134 million ![Net assets acquired for Salesforce.org were considerably smaller](image1).  Furthermore, ClickSoftware’s fair value allocation explicitly included intangible assets, with \$215 million for developed technology and \$61 million for customer relationships [7], contributing to a total of \$276 million in intangible assets ![ClickSoftware had substantial intangible assets like developed technology and customer relationships](image7). In contrast, while the MapAnything acquisition (which shares some similarities in allocation discussion [1]) also mentions developed technology and customer relationships, the Salesforce.org allocation as presented in the provided images does not detail specific intangible assets in the same way, although it lists "Other current and noncurrent assets" and "Other assets" which might encompass some intangibles.

Another notable difference is the presence of a "Deferred tax asset" of \$59 million in the Salesforce.org acquisition ![Salesforce.org had a deferred tax asset](image1), while ClickSoftware's allocation shows a "Deferred tax liability" of \$26 million ![ClickSoftware had a deferred tax liability](image8). Both acquisitions involved adjustments for liabilities such as accounts payable, accrued expenses, unearned revenue, and deferred taxes, indicating standard accounting practices for business combinations.

In summary, both acquisitions allocated fair value to net assets acquired and recognized goodwill, but ClickSoftware was a significantly larger acquisition with explicitly detailed and substantial intangible assets, while Salesforce.org was smaller and presented a deferred tax asset instead of a liability in its fair value allocation, reflecting variations in their financial impacts and asset compositions.

From 2019 to 2020, there were shifts in net cash from operating, investing, and financing activities. Net cash provided by operating activities saw a decrease of $0.3 billion, primarily due to increased working capital needs and higher cash payments for asset impairment, despite higher net earnings [6].  The cash flow statement provides a detailed breakdown of operating activities, showing a decrease from $10,090 million in 2019 to $9,812 million in 2020, reflecting this change. ![Details of operating activities cash flow](image1)  In contrast, net cash used in investing activities decreased by $0.7 billion. This improvement was mainly driven by reduced cash outflows related to the deconsolidation of RBH in 2019 and lower capital expenditures in 2020, although this was partially offset by increased cash collateral for derivatives [2].  The investing activities section of the cash flow statement shows a move from net cash used of -$1,200 million in 2019 to -$551 million in 2020, indicating less cash used in investing activities year over year. ![Details of investing activities cash flow](image1)  However, net cash used in financing activities increased by $0.4 billion due to higher payments to noncontrolling interests and increased dividend payouts, which was only partially offset by debt activity [3]. The financing activities statement highlights this increase in cash used, moving from -$8,061 million in 2019 to -$8,496 million in 2020. ![Details of financing activities cash flow](image4) Despite the decrease in operating cash flow and increase in financing cash usage, the reduced cash used in investing activities contributed to an overall net increase in cash, cash equivalents, and restricted cash by $420 million from the beginning to the end of 2020 [image4].

In summary, while operating and financing activities exerted downward pressure on the cash balance, the significant reduction in cash used for investing activities was substantial enough to result in a net increase in the company's overall cash balance at the end of 2020 compared to 2019.

Toyota's executive remuneration system is designed to motivate directors to enhance the company's medium to long-term corporate value [5]. This system incorporates both fixed and performance-based components, ensuring that remuneration is effectively tied to corporate performance while also reflecting individual responsibilities and performance [3, 1].  The structure includes monthly fixed remuneration and performance-linked remuneration, with the latter being calculated based on consolidated operating income, the volatility of Toyota's share price, and individual performance evaluations [1, 2].

To evaluate business performance, Toyota uses consolidated operating income as a key indicator, assessing the degree of attainment of the current fiscal year's income against a set reference value [7].

![Toyota uses consolidated operating income and share price volatility to evaluate business performance, referencing specific values and methods.](image7)

Alongside operating income, the volatility of Toyota's share price is also considered, comparing it against the Nikkei stock average to evaluate market performance [7]. These indicators are crucial for determining the performance-linked portion of executive compensation [11]. The remuneration structure itself is designed with performance-linked elements, alongside fixed and share-based compensation [2].

![The remuneration structure for Toyota executives includes monthly fixed pay, bonuses, and share-based compensation, categorized by director and audit & supervisory board member roles.](image2)

Furthermore, Toyota recognizes the significance of shareholder returns as a key element of its management policy [9].  The company aims for stable and continuous dividend payments, targeting a consolidated payout ratio of 30% [9].  This commitment to shareholder value is reflected in the company's dividend history.

![Toyota's dividend per share and total payment amounts over several years, indicating consistent shareholder returns.](image1)

In conclusion, Toyota's executive remuneration evaluation directly reflects their business performance through indicators like operating income and share price volatility, and it indirectly reflects shareholder value indicators through considerations of long-term corporate value and dividend payout strategies.

Caterpillar's total sales and revenues experienced a significant surge in 2021, climbing by $9.223 billion, or 22 percent, to reach $50.971 billion compared to $41.748 billion in 2020 [9].  This impressive growth was largely fueled by a substantial increase in sales volume and favorable price realization, alongside shifts in dealer inventories [9].  ![Full Year 2021 vs. Full Year 2020 Sales & Revenues broken down by Sales Volume, Price Realization, Currency and Financial Products](image5).  Specifically, sales volume contributed $7.563 billion and price realization added $932 million to the revenue increase in 2021 compared to the previous year, as shown in the provided breakdown of revenue changes.

The Construction Industries segment stood out with a remarkable sales increase of 31 percent, reaching $22.106 billion in 2021 [3]. This surge was attributed to higher sales volume, favorable price realization, and positive currency impacts [3]. Similarly, Resource Industries witnessed a substantial 27 percent sales growth in the fourth quarter of 2021, driven by increased sales volume and favorable price realization [6].  Energy & Transportation also contributed to the overall growth, with a 16 percent increase in sales for the full year 2021, reaching $20.287 billion [11]. ![Sales and Revenues by Segment in 2021, including breakdown by Sales Volume and Price Realization](image8). As seen in the segment sales breakdown, Construction Industries experienced the most significant sales volume increase of $4.063 billion, while Energy & Transportation saw the largest contribution from "other" factors, which included $811 million.

In conclusion, the increase in sales volume and favorable price realization were key drivers of Caterpillar's revenue growth in 2021, with Construction Industries exhibiting the most significant improvement in sales volume.

In 2020, Consumer Banking's financial performance experienced a downturn compared to the previous year [2]. This was reflected in a decrease in net income, primarily due to a combination of reduced revenue streams, an increase in provisions set aside for potential credit losses, and higher overall expenses [2].  Specifically, net interest income within Consumer Banking declined as a result of lower interest rates, although the impact was partially mitigated by growth in both deposit and loan balances [2].  Noninterest income also saw a decrease, primarily driven by lower service charges and reduced card income [2]. ![Image 6 shows that Consumer Banking net income decreased by 50% from 2019 to 2020.](image6) The net income for Consumer Banking segment saw a significant 50% decrease from $12,962 million in 2019 to $6,507 million in 2020 [image6].  Similarly, the total revenue, net of interest expense for Consumer Banking also decreased by 14% during this period [image6].

Global Wealth & Investment Management (GWIM), which includes both Merrill Lynch Global Wealth Management (MLGWM) and Bank of America Private Bank [11], also faced a decrease in revenue during 2020 [7, 12].  MLGWM revenue experienced a five percent decrease [7], and Bank of America Private Bank's revenue also declined by four percent [12].  ![Image 7 shows that MLGWM revenue and Bank of America Private Bank revenue both decreased in 2020 compared to 2019.](image7)  Specifically, MLGWM revenue was $15,292 million in 2020 compared to $16,112 million in 2019, while Bank of America Private Bank revenue was $3,292 million in 2020, down from $3,426 million in 2019 [image7].

Overall, both Consumer Banking and Global Wealth & Investment Management segments of Bank of America experienced a decline in financial performance in terms of revenue and net income when comparing 2020 to 2019.

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, significant resources were directed towards both immediate relief and long-term rural development initiatives. Projects aimed at mitigating the impact of COVID-19 spanned across various states in India, with a considerable amount of 70.00 crore allocated for pan-India COVID relief efforts, alongside 0.60 crore in Haryana, 0.20 crore in Maharashtra, and further distributed amounts in other states, showcasing a widespread response to the health crisis ![COVID relief projects across India with significant spending in pan-India projects and Maharashtra](image4).  These initiatives were crucial in addressing the urgent healthcare needs arising from the pandemic.

Conversely, rural development projects, while also extensive, were implemented across a diverse range of states including Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, and Gujarat, with varying amounts allocated to each region, such as 1.17 crore, 1.26 crore, and 0.28 crore respectively, indicating a more geographically dispersed approach to development [image3]. Further investments in rural development are evident in states like Punjab and Maharashtra, with projects in Firozpur, Amritsar, and Nashik, demonstrating a sustained commitment to enhancing rural infrastructure and livelihoods ![Rural development projects in Punjab and Maharashtra with varying budgets](image5, image2).

Examining the implementation modes, both COVID relief and rural development projects predominantly utilized implementing agencies, as indicated by the 'No' in the "Direct Implementation" column across the project lists, suggesting a reliance on external partners for project execution across both categories ![Project implementation modes showing reliance on implementing agencies](image1). However, some COVID relief initiatives, particularly larger scale ones, may have involved direct implementation to ensure rapid and efficient aid distribution during the crisis.

In conclusion, while both COVID relief and rural development projects received substantial investment, COVID relief efforts saw a higher concentration of spending likely due to the immediate and urgent nature of the pandemic response, whereas rural development projects were more distributed geographically.  Both types of projects largely relied on implementation through external agencies.

Actuarial assumptions are critical in determining defined benefit obligations, as they involve estimations of future events to calculate the present value of future benefit entitlements [3]. These assumptions encompass factors such as discount rates, expected compensation increases, pension progression, and mortality rates [3].  Discount rates, for example, saw slight increases in Euro, U.S. dollar, British pound, and Swiss franc from 2020 to 2021 ![Discount rates slightly increased from 2020 to 2021](image2). Similarly, compensation increase and pension progression assumptions also experienced changes across different regions during this period ![Compensation increase and pension progression changed in UK and Switzerland](image3).

The sensitivity of the defined benefit obligation to these assumptions highlights their impact. For instance, a decrease in the discount rate or increases in compensation and pension progression would generally lead to an increase in the defined benefit obligation, and vice versa ![Defined benefit obligation is sensitive to changes in discount rate, compensation increase and pension progression](image7).  Changes in demographic and financial assumptions contributed to actuarial gains and losses, impacting the overall financial figures from 2020 to 2021 ![Changes in actuarial assumptions led to actuarial gains and losses](image4).  The table shows the reconciliation of the defined benefit obligation, plan assets and net defined benefit balance, reflecting the cumulative effect of various factors including changes in actuarial assumptions over the fiscal years 2020 and 2021 ![Reconciliation of defined benefit obligation, plan assets and net defined benefit balance between 2020 and 2021](image1).

Changes in actuarial assumptions significantly influenced the defined benefit obligation between 2020 and 2021.

In 2020, there were notable shifts within the components of Risk-Weighted Assets (RWA). Specifically, market risk RWA saw an increase due to heightened market volatility impacting Regulatory VaR [8]. Similarly, credit risk RWA also experienced an increase, primarily driven by derivatives exposures and investment securities, further influenced by market volatility and acquisitions [12]. You can see the detailed changes in credit risk, market risk, and operational risk RWA in the provided table. ![Detailed changes in Credit, Market, and Operational RWA components between 2019 and 2020.](image3).  Conversely, operational risk RWA decreased in 2020, which was attributed to a reduction in litigation-related losses [1]. Despite these component-level changes in RWA, when we examine External TLAC as a percentage of RWA, we observe a slight decrease from 49.9% in 2019 to 47.7% in 2020 [image7].  Therefore, while various components of RWA changed in 2020, the External TLAC as a percentage of RWA experienced a slight decrease from 2019 to 2020.

McDonald's experienced shifts in revenue composition and growth between its U.S. and International Operated Markets segments from 2019 to 2020.  Total revenues, encompassing both company-operated sales and franchised revenues, saw a decrease in both segments, but more significantly in the International Operated Markets. The U.S. segment witnessed a smaller decrease of 2%, while the International Operated Markets faced a substantial 17% decline in total revenues ![Total Revenue changes in US and IOM](image4).  This difference is further highlighted when considering restaurant margins, where International Operated Markets experienced a 13% decrease [2], a more significant drop compared to the U.S. segment, though specific margin changes for the U.S. segment are not explicitly detailed in the provided images ![Restaurant margin changes in International Operated Markets](image5).

These changes were significantly influenced by the COVID-19 pandemic [2, 8, 10].  The International Operated Markets were particularly affected by temporary restaurant closures and operational limitations, leading to more pronounced revenue declines [12].  While the U.S. market showed positive sales performance, this was counteracted by substantial marketing support initiatives aimed at accelerating recovery, including franchisee incentives and the "Thank You Meals" program for first responders [8, 5].  Furthermore, both segments incurred incremental COVID-19 related expenses, such as employee costs and personal protective equipment, which impacted company-operated margins [4, 6]. Despite the challenges, strategic marketing investments and growth in delivery services did have a positive impact on comparable sales in the latter half of 2020 [10].

In conclusion, from 2019 to 2020, McDonald's U.S. segment experienced a minor revenue decrease, while the International Operated Markets faced a much larger decline, primarily due to the impact of COVID-19, although strategic initiatives partially mitigated negative trends later in the year.

Accumulated depreciation notably influenced the net value of both solar energy systems and overall property, plant, and equipment.  Solar energy systems are recorded at cost, reduced by accumulated depreciation [6].  As illustrated, solar energy systems, net value decreased from $6,138 million in 2019 to $5,979 million in 2020, alongside an increase in accumulated depreciation from $723 million to $955 million during the same period ![Solar energy systems net value and accumulated depreciation from 2019 to 2020](image5).  This rise in accumulated depreciation directly contributed to the reduction in the net value of solar energy systems.

Conversely, for the broader category of property, plant, and equipment, while accumulated depreciation also increased from $3,734 million in 2019 to $5,117 million in 2020, the total value before depreciation saw a more substantial increase.  Consequently, the net value of property, plant, and equipment actually rose from $10,396 million to $12,747 million ![Property, plant, and equipment net value and accumulated depreciation from 2019 to 2020](image3).  This indicates that despite increased depreciation expenses [2], the acquisition of new assets outpaced the depreciation, leading to an overall increase in the net value of property, plant, and equipment.

In summary, accumulated depreciation reduced the net value of solar energy systems while, despite increased depreciation, the net value of property, plant, and equipment increased due to larger asset acquisitions.

Accenture's total shareholders' equity has seen a consistent rise over the years. This increase is significantly influenced by the company's net income and comprehensive income.  Net income, a crucial component, reflects the profitability from operations.  In 2018, Accenture's net income was $4,214,594, which increased to $4,846,241 in 2019, and further to $5,185,313 in 2020, demonstrating a positive trend in profitability ![Showing the net income, other comprehensive income, and comprehensive income for 2020, 2019, and 2018](image2).  Comprehensive income, which includes net income and other items like foreign currency translation adjustments and cash flow hedges, also plays a vital role. Accenture's comprehensive income followed a similar upward trajectory, from $3,730,974 in 2018 to $4,575,086 in 2019, and reaching $5,472,296 in 2020 [2].  These income figures directly contribute to retained earnings, a major component of shareholders' equity, thereby driving the overall growth in total shareholders' equity over the period from 2018 to 2020 [11].

Net income and comprehensive income positively impacted the total shareholders' equity growth at Accenture from 2018 to 2020.

In 2021, Wells Fargo strategically reshaped its business by divesting Wells Fargo Asset Management (WFAM), a move finalized on November 1st [1, 7]. This sale significantly altered their Assets Under Management (AUM) [10]. Prior to the sale, WFAM managed a diverse portfolio, including money market funds and various asset classes, contributing to Wells Fargo's fee income based on a percentage of the market value of the AUM [4]. The tangible effect of this divestment is clearly illustrated in the decline of WFAM's total assets under management across 2019, 2020, and culminating in zero by the end of 2021, directly due to the sale ![WFAM assets under management decreased to zero in 2021 due to the sale](image5).

While the disposal of WFAM led to a decrease in managed assets, it also generated a substantial net gain of $269 million for Wells Fargo [7].  Despite the reduction in AUM-related fee income, the overall balance sheet experienced only a modest decrease in total assets from 2020 to 2021, as shown in the balance sheet data ![A modest decrease in total assets is observed from 2020 to 2021](image1). This slight decrease was influenced by the timing of investment portfolio cash deployment towards the end of 2021, which was partially offset by increased equity securities related to venture capital activities [12].  Furthermore, the company's strategic actions, including the WFAM sale, contributed to a substantial net income of $21.5 billion in 2021, reflecting an improved financial profile [5].

The sale of WFAM in 2021 led to a significant reduction in Wells Fargo's reported Assets Under Management and contributed to a minor decrease in total assets on their balance sheet, alongside generating a notable one-time gain.

From 2016 to 2020, Lovisa experienced a significant international expansion, growing its store count from 250 to 435 across 15 countries [1, image1]. This growth was strategically driven by targeting high-traffic shopping precincts and leveraging a refined global store model, characterized by a target 50 square metre floor space and a consistent layout, enabling rapid and low-cost store fit-outs, averaging just 14 days per store [8].  This efficient model facilitated quick roll-outs in new regions.

![Store expansion from 2016 to 2020](image1)

Lovisa's strategy involved leveraging existing international territories and expanding into new markets, aiming for one new trial territory annually [image2].  A key achievement during this period was the successful establishment and growth in major international markets like the United Kingdom, France, and the United States, with substantial store openings in these regions [image2, 9].  This international roll-out is considered a key driver for Lovisa's future growth [9].

![Lovisa's growth strategy pillars](image2)

However, Lovisa operates in a highly competitive fast fashion jewellery sector with relatively low barriers to entry [2].  To mitigate risks associated with changing customer preferences and market demands, Lovisa employs a large product team focused on product innovation and trend identification [5, 6].  This team ensures a broad and fashionable product range, aligning with global trends, which is crucial for maintaining a competitive edge [6].  Despite the competitive landscape, Lovisa's established business model, IT systems, and brand recognition create a substantial barrier for new entrants [2, 5].

The evolution of Lovisa’s international strategy from 2016 to 2020 showcases a period of rapid expansion and strategic market penetration, marked by efficient store roll-outs and a focus on trend-driven product offerings, though constantly navigating the challenges of a competitive and dynamic industry.

The financial performance in 2020 experienced significant changes compared to the previous year, primarily due to external economic factors [5].  A key indicator, net interest income (NII), saw a decrease from  $\S30.462$ million in 2019 to $\S27.578$ million in 2020, representing a 9.5% reduction. This decline in NII is clearly depicted in the financial data comparing 2020 with 2019, where NII dropped from 30,462 to 27,578 [image5].  This decrease in net interest income is further elaborated as being a result of lower average market interest rates in major currencies when contrasted with 2019 [9].

Simultaneously, interest expense also decreased year-on-year, falling from $\S24.233$ million in 2019 to $\S14.178$ million in 2020 [image1].  Despite the decrease in interest expense, the more substantial reduction in interest income, from $\S54.695$ million to $\S41.756$ million [image1], led to the overall decline in net interest income.  The reduction in interest income was primarily attributed to lower average interest rates, although partly mitigated by growth in interest-earning assets [9].

The net operating income before changes in expected credit losses consequently decreased to $\S50.429$ million in 2020 from $\S56.098$ million in 2019 [image5]. This reduction in net operating income, influenced by the lowered NII, contributed to a decrease in profit before tax, which fell from $\S13.347$ million in 2019 to $\S8.777$ million in 2020 [image5].  Ultimately, the overall profitability, reflected in the reported profit before tax, was significantly impacted by these changes, decreasing by 34% [1].

In conclusion, the decrease in net interest income, driven by lower interest rates, coupled with a reduction in interest expense, resulted in a lower net operating income, which significantly impacted the overall profitability of the organization in 2020 compared to 2019.

Net investment income experienced a decrease from 2020 to 2021, as shown in the investment income statement.  ![Net investment income decreased in 2021 compared to 2020](image6). This decline is further elaborated by the decrease in interest and other investment income, which fell by 44.4%, and a more modest increase in dividend income of 3.5% from 2020 to 2021 [Image6]. The decrease in overall investment income is attributed to lower returns from short-term investments and fixed maturity securities, a consequence of prevailing low interest rates during that period [9].

Conversely, railroad operating earnings demonstrated a significant increase between 2020 and 2021, as detailed in the railroad operating revenues and expenses report. ![Railroad operating earnings increased in 2021 compared to 2020](image8).  This positive change is reflected in a 15.7% rise in pre-tax earnings [5] and a 16.1% increase in after-tax earnings [6].  The growth in railroad operating earnings was driven by a 6.9% increase in volumes and a 3.5% increase in average revenue per car/unit, stemming from business mix adjustments and increased fuel surcharge revenue due to higher fuel prices [5].  Furthermore, improvements in productivity also contributed to this earnings growth, although these gains were partially offset by increased fuel prices and volume-related costs [6].

In summary, net investment income decreased due to lower interest rates impacting investment returns, while railroad operating earnings increased driven by higher volumes, revenue per car/unit, and productivity improvements.

From 2019 to 2021, there has been a notable increase in the company's cost of revenues, escalating from RMB 16,761 million to RMB 21,840 million [image6]. This surge is primarily driven by service costs, which constitute the major portion of the cost of revenues, and other costs of revenues, both exhibiting growth [image6]. Service costs are composed of content costs, fees to content creators, and content delivery costs [8], while other costs include agency fees and payment channel fees, which saw an increase [2].  ![Cost of revenues increased significantly, with service costs as the main component.](image6)  The rise in other cost of revenues is specifically attributed to higher agency fees and payment channel fees [2]. Operating expenses also saw an upward trend during this period, increasing from RMB 4,744 million to RMB 6,687 million [image2]. This increase is observed in both selling and marketing expenses and general and administrative expenses [image2].  ![Operating expenses also increased, with both selling and marketing and general and administrative expenses contributing.](image2)  Selling and marketing expenses are mainly composed of branding and user acquisition costs [12], whereas general and administrative expenses include R&D expenses, salaries for administrative and R&D personnel, and professional service expenses [6, 10].  Notably, research and development expenses, a component of general and administrative expenses, increased from RMB 1,159 million in 2019 to RMB 2,339 million in 2021 [5].

Despite the increase in both cost of revenues and operating expenses, the company's revenue also grew from RMB 25,434 million to RMB 31,244 million [image1].  ![Revenue experienced growth from 2019 to 2021.](image1)  However, the cost of revenues as a percentage of total revenue increased from 65.9% to 69.9% and operating expenses as a percentage of total revenue also increased from 18.7% to 21.4% [image3].  This indicates that while revenue is growing, costs are growing at a faster rate, impacting profitability margins as reflected in the operating profit which decreased from RMB 4,622 million in 2019 to RMB 3,800 million in 2021 [image3].

The changes in cost structure and operating expenses from 2019 to 2021 suggest a period of investment and expansion, potentially in content, technology, and user acquisition, which has led to increased costs relative to revenue, impacting operating profitability.

IBM's financial landscape between 2019 and 2020 reveals shifts in key areas, starting with noncurrent assets which saw an increase of $^{\S3,039}$ million [7]. This rise in noncurrent assets is further detailed as being influenced by deferred taxes and prepaid pension assets, although it was partially offset by a decrease in long-term financing receivables [9].  In conjunction with asset changes, long-term debt also experienced a slight increase, moving from $54,102 million in 2019 to $54,355 million in 2020, as shown in the balance sheet snapshot ![Noncurrent assets and long-term debt experienced slight increase from 2019 to 2020](image8).

However, looking at the broader debt picture, total debt actually decreased by $^{\oplus1,361}$ million [12], and Global Financing debt also saw a reduction of $^{\S3,560}$ million [5]. This overall debt reduction is reflected in the segment assets and liabilities overview ![Global financing debt and total equity decreased, while client financing assets also decreased](image2), which highlights a decrease in total debt for Global Financing from $24,727 million to $21,167 million.  Despite the increase in long-term debt portion, the financing activities shifted from being a net source of cash of $^{\S9,042}$ million in 2019 to a net use of cash of $^{\S9,721}$ million in 2020 [2], a significant change illustrated in cash flow activities ![Financing activities changed from net cash inflow to net cash outflow between 2019 and 2020](image5).

Furthermore, IBM's total equity experienced a decrease of $^{\S258}$ million, primarily attributed to dividend payouts and a decline in accumulated other comprehensive income, even though this was partially mitigated by net income [6]. The return on equity for Global Financing remained constant at 25.8% despite these changes, as illustrated in the return on equity calculation ![Global Financing return on equity remained the same at 25.8% in both 2019 and 2020](image3).

In conclusion, while IBM's noncurrent assets and long-term debt saw minor increases, the company's overall financial standing in 2020 was marked by a net decrease in total debt and equity, alongside a shift towards using cash in financing activities compared to the previous year.
